description: The Querying Microsoft SQL Server 2014 show is for those who are seeking to validate their skills and knowledge in writing Transact SQL queries.  The show helps the certification candidate by describing, discussing and demonstrating SQL query writing skills in multiple areas. The episodes will cover the advanced SELECT statements, grouping sets, aggregates, SET operators, basic T-SQL programming and Performance Improvement.  The show focuses heavily on demonstrating the syntax and logic of writing the queries.  This particular exam is intended for candidates that have two or more years of experience in writing queries with Microsoft SQL Server
name: Microsoft SQL Server 2014 - 70-461
subtitle: Querying Microsoft SQL Server 2014

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie come back to finish up their discussion and primer of working with the Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Management interface. They also discuss the different default databases you'll encounter after installation, which includes the System Databases (Master, MSDB, Model, TempDB) and User created databases.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into the basics of SQL querying. They start by defining what SQL is and how it differs from Transact SQL. They also explain the 3 categories of T-SQL statements which are Data Manipulation Language (DML), Data Definition Language(DDL), and Data Control Language(DCL). Finally, they explain the Key-In Order vs. the Processing Order.
episodes.title: SQL Querying Basics

Remember, also,

Is that when we have two things that

one is part of that kind of proprietary

The idea and the best practice is to try

If you're trying to choose and go I

Best default is to actually

Only if there's a special reason,

So who knows what would happen there,

So just kind of remember that those

the background.

72

Now, the unusual thing about T-SQL,
Transact SQL,

73

is that even within Transact SQL,

really distinct sub-languages, too.

75

Can you imagine that, right?

76
00:04:24.410 --> 00:04:28.645
SQL breaks off into lord knows how many
different dialects that there are, and

77

And so here's something that we

87

88

90

So normally in this there's gonna be

94
00:05:37.715 --> 00:05:40.290
UPDATE means of course,
we're actually gonna be updating that, and

95
00:05:40.290 --> 00:05:42.940
then even deleting that

96
00:05:42.940 --> 00:05:45.920
So normally, all that is done

97
00:05:45.920 --> 00:05:50.320
And we'll actually see some of

98
00:05:50.320 --> 00:05:53.820
I believe, during our entire

So we'll see the majority of

Then, as you want to create databases

102
00:06:07.813 --> 00:06:11.460
This is what helps us to

103

So when you're creating different objects,

104
00:06:13.325 --> 00:06:15.760
well let me see if I can
scroll on over here.

105
00:06:15.760 --> 00:06:18.340
Remember that here it is on my SQL server,

00:06:18.340 --> 00:06:21.753
over here on the left hand
side in the Object Explorer.

107
00:06:21.753 --> 00:06:26.070
Well that means all these different ones
that we have here with the plus signs, and

108
00:06:26.070 --> 00:06:30.290
of course, even the minus signs,
these are considered our database objects.

109
00:06:30.290 --> 00:06:32.718
So, if we're creating views,
if we're creating tables,

110
00:06:32.718 --> 00:06:34.900
if we're creating databases themselves.

111
00:06:34.900 --> 00:06:37.950
These are considered objects and
when we do something like

112
00:06:37.950 --> 00:06:41.540
that using the actual querying language,
well this is where we do it.

113
00:06:41.540 --> 00:06:44.390
We are defining those
database objects here, and

114
00:06:44.390 --> 00:06:47.550
this is where we can create
whatever we want to.

115
00:06:47.550 --> 00:06:51.040
We can change it up and
we can even drop that particular one so

116
00:06:51.040 --> 00:06:53.320
it's not actually used anymore as well.

117
00:06:53.320 --> 00:06:54.520
When that drops out,

118
00:06:54.520 --> 00:06:57.820
it normally does actually take it

119
00:06:57.820 --> 00:07:01.000
So there is

120
00:07:01.000 --> 00:07:05.780
Now, normally, when you start taking a

121
00:07:05.780 --> 00:07:11.360
there's a lot of power behind what you

122
00:07:11.360 --> 00:07:14.220
And so, you do need to be careful,
you wanna make sure

00:07:14.220 --> 00:07:18.790

124
00:07:18.790 --> 00:07:22.550
Especially when you start talking about
dropping tables, or inserting and

125
00:07:22.550 --> 00:07:23.920

126
00:07:23.920 --> 00:07:29.170
This can really mess up a database to
the point where it becomes unusable.

127
00:07:29.170 --> 00:07:32.090
So also, of course, then that means
hopefully you're running your great

128
00:07:32.090 --> 00:07:34.010
backups on everything that you're doing.

129
00:07:34.010 --> 00:07:37.670
But at the same time,
don't just run these just because you go,

130
00:07:37.670 --> 00:07:40.120
I want a chance to run this and
see what it's like.

131
00:07:40.120 --> 00:07:43.340
If you do, download a sample database and

132
00:07:43.340 --> 00:07:45.900
Don't do it against your
actually true production data.

133
00:07:45.900 --> 00:07:48.440
Losing data like that becomes just about

134
00:07:48.440 --> 00:07:51.810
incalculable about how much value
that data was actually worth.

135
00:07:51.810 --> 00:07:53.230
>> Real quick question on this Ronnie.

136
00:07:53.230 --> 00:07:57.140
I understand the differences
that you're setting before us.

137
00:07:57.140 --> 00:08:00.261
With the data manipulation language
you're manipulating the data.

138
00:08:00.261 --> 00:08:03.291
You can select it,
I need to insert something into it.

139
00:08:03.291 --> 00:08:08.708
Update and delete, but I jump over to the
DDL and I see some similarities there and

140
00:08:08.708 --> 00:08:13.980
it seems to me there's probably
an inherent danger for us to get confused.

141
00:08:13.980 --> 00:08:17.538
Update seems a lot like alter,
and delete seems a lot like drop.

142
00:08:17.538 --> 00:08:20.010
Is that something we're gonna
have to look out for, or

143
00:08:20.010 --> 00:08:23.251
are we gonna address that in upcoming
issues or are we gonna do that now?

144
00:08:23.251 --> 00:08:26.015
>> Yeah, we're gonna actually gonna
address that in upcoming issues here when

145
00:08:26.015 --> 00:08:28.310
we talk about the differences
between this, right?

146
00:08:28.310 --> 00:08:32.696
So this is really actually altering and
dropping the entire tables themselves,

147
00:08:32.696 --> 00:08:37.357
whereas updating and deleting normally is
referring to columns of data that we have.

148
00:08:37.357 --> 00:08:40.237
And so normally when you're updating,
you're adding in a new column.

149
00:08:40.237 --> 00:08:43.430
And when you're deleting,
you're actually removing a column.

150
00:08:43.430 --> 00:08:46.760
And the problem is, there's
actually data now attached to that.

151
00:08:46.760 --> 00:08:51.246
So you're actually being able to do stuff
like that by adding in stuff to do that.

152
00:08:51.246 --> 00:08:55.860
Whereas in altering here, you're literally
altering the structure of that table or

153
00:08:55.860 --> 00:08:58.687
you're actually getting
rid of that table as well.

154
00:08:58.687 --> 00:09:01.758
So you do have to be careful with these
different objects here when you start

155
00:09:01.758 --> 00:09:05.500
to take a look, and the same thing with
views and some of the different ones here.

156
00:09:05.500 --> 00:09:08.530
But this is where it comes
down to understanding when you

157
00:09:08.530 --> 00:09:11.640
start talking about this type of
language and what we're dealing with.

158
00:09:11.640 --> 00:09:15.115
And we'll get into it when we get into the
select clauses here in just a moment and

159
00:09:15.115 --> 00:09:16.660
trying to deal with it a little bit more.

160
00:09:16.660 --> 00:09:19.700
There's one more,
which is what we call DCL, okay?

161
00:09:19.700 --> 00:09:23.416
So this is used to manage
security permissions.

162
00:09:23.416 --> 00:09:26.260
Essentially you're gonna be granting,
revoking, and denying.

163
00:09:26.260 --> 00:09:29.990
Now in this, it's usually like, wow,
there's only three different things, but

164
00:09:29.990 --> 00:09:34.250
trust me, it's actually much more
difficult than you believe here, okay?

165
00:09:34.250 --> 00:09:39.090
Someone like me being able to query and
being able to create reports,

166
00:09:39.090 --> 00:09:41.850
okay, off of the database that I have.

167
00:09:41.850 --> 00:09:46.143
So, for example, if you're actually
someone that's actually depended upon to

168
00:09:46.143 --> 00:09:50.244
run reports, to say hey, I need to find
out how many people are actually in this

169
00:09:50.244 --> 00:09:52.180
department versus this one.

170
00:09:52.180 --> 00:09:57.340
How much revenue did this company bring
versus this company or department?

171
00:09:57.340 --> 00:10:00.795
Well, then you're probably
really using this DML language,

172
00:10:00.795 --> 00:10:02.626
pretty much all the time, okay?

173
00:10:02.626 --> 00:10:06.765
If you're actually a database designer and
a creator, okay,

174
00:10:06.765 --> 00:10:12.309
you're probably gonna be sticking in with
this DDL language here, and then you'll

175
00:10:12.309 --> 00:10:17.719
be using the manipulations language to
help to populate that data as well, okay?

176
00:10:17.719 --> 00:10:20.964
But here in the DCL,
this is about literally controlling

177
00:10:20.964 --> 00:10:25.302
access to the entirety of your databases
and everything that you have here.

178
00:10:25.302 --> 00:10:30.054
This is more where you actually do have
that database administrator, right,

179
00:10:30.054 --> 00:10:35.094
that comes in and they actually manage the
entirety of how you access the database,

you do have a table that has existing

467
00:27:04.790 --> 00:27:09.600
data, adding in an additional column or
an additional two columns may end up

468
00:27:09.600 --> 00:27:13.600
violating what we call some different
referential integrity constraints here.

469
00:27:13.600 --> 00:27:15.460
So we do wanna be careful with that.

470
00:27:15.460 --> 00:27:20.410
But adding in to a table that's not yet
connected to my database, no big deal.

471
00:27:20.410 --> 00:27:24.500
I can continue to modify that and
alter that particular table as well.

472
00:27:26.330 --> 00:27:30.560
Now, there's a couple of other commands
we also need to focus in on here at

473
00:27:30.560 --> 00:27:31.940
the M2, okay.

474
00:27:31.940 --> 00:27:36.290
One is, what if you actually have a table
and now you want to get rid of it, okay?

475
00:27:36.290 --> 00:27:40.120
Well, let me show you what you
can also can do here too, okay.

476
00:27:40.120 --> 00:27:43.790
So, the good thing is, if you have
the tools that are available to you, okay,

477
00:27:43.790 --> 00:27:46.130
which is right over here, okay.

478
00:27:46.130 --> 00:27:50.910
So, if I wanted to get rid of the table
very easily, I simply right-click, and

479
00:27:50.910 --> 00:27:52.980
notice I can select Delete.

480
00:27:52.980 --> 00:27:56.260
And when I do that it brings up
this little property window for me,

481
00:27:56.260 --> 00:27:59.340
and it says Delete Object at the top.

482
00:27:59.340 --> 00:28:03.540
And I simply click OK, and
then it's deleted out of there.

483
00:28:03.540 --> 00:28:06.395
But what if you actually
need to do this but

484
00:28:06.395 --> 00:28:10.321
you do not have the ability to
do it by using that command?

485
00:28:10.321 --> 00:28:12.852
In other words you're told,
you can do this, but

486
00:28:12.852 --> 00:28:16.500
which of the following commands
in gonna allow you to do this?

487
00:28:16.500 --> 00:28:21.110
Well this is why we are focusing
in on this one instead.

488
00:28:22.630 --> 00:28:28.040
So if I wanted to delete
an object out completely, here,

489
00:28:28.040 --> 00:28:32.990
I have now a DROP TABLE
command that we can use too.

490
00:28:32.990 --> 00:28:38.135
So this one is saying if you can
find the object that is labeled as

491
00:28:38.135 --> 00:28:44.390
dbo.NewEmployees2 and
also one that begins with a U or

492
00:28:44.390 --> 00:28:47.720
whatever the next object is for
the unique one here, and it's not null.

493
00:28:47.720 --> 00:28:50.190
In other words, it has values in it.

494
00:28:50.190 --> 00:28:51.770
Drop the table, okay?

495
00:28:51.770 --> 00:28:53.480
So that's what it's telling it to do.

496
00:28:53.480 --> 00:28:58.540
So look inside of it, take a look, if it's
not null then you can drop that table.

497
00:28:58.540 --> 00:29:03.400
So that's actually a great command for you
to be able to also run if you needed to.

498
00:29:03.400 --> 00:29:07.800
Now, at this point, there is no
data in it so I'm not gonna run it

499
00:29:07.800 --> 00:29:10.820
cuz I don't wanna delete it because I have
something else we're gonna show as well.

500
00:29:10.820 --> 00:29:14.980
Okay, but overall though,
you do want to make sure that you know

501
00:29:14.980 --> 00:29:18.530
what command is not only gonna
be able to generate a table, but

502
00:29:18.530 --> 00:29:21.610
be able to drop a table, if you need to,
if you need to get out of it.

503
00:29:21.610 --> 00:29:25.840
So, remember that it's actually something
that looks fairly similar to this.

504
00:29:25.840 --> 00:29:27.800
Now, in this sense,

505
00:29:27.800 --> 00:29:31.735
perfectly fine, something that
you do need to do sometimes here.

506
00:29:31.735 --> 00:29:34.350
Where if you're like me you might create
multiple objects and then realize

507
00:29:34.350 --> 00:29:37.900
that it's actually all wrong and you do
need to get those things out of there.

508
00:29:37.900 --> 00:29:41.750
Again, fairly easy enough to right-click,
but if you absolutely have to do it using

509
00:29:41.750 --> 00:29:44.500
the query window,
this is the way you're going to do it.

510
00:29:44.500 --> 00:29:46.860
Now the other thing that we can do

511
00:29:46.860 --> 00:29:51.260
is that there is another command
which is also called ALTER COLUMN.

512
00:29:51.260 --> 00:29:54.390
Now if you're like me the first time
you think about it like alter a column

513
00:29:55.410 --> 00:29:57.510
well what do you really
have to alter in a column?

514
00:29:57.510 --> 00:30:00.580
Well I always thought well what
if I wanted to remove a column,

515
00:30:00.580 --> 00:30:02.870
well that's not the way you'd do it, okay.

516
00:30:02.870 --> 00:30:07.070
This one will absolutely only
allow you to do this to modify

517
00:30:07.070 --> 00:30:12.470
that column's Data Type and
that is the key to alter a column okay.

518
00:30:12.470 --> 00:30:16.370
So if I wanted to change,
notice that remember when I added in

519
00:30:16.370 --> 00:30:20.260
the email to Employee2,
it was 100 characters, right here?

520
00:30:21.750 --> 00:30:27.202
So if I scroll over here
to the left hand side,

521
00:30:27.202 --> 00:30:33.239
and let's verify that
that actually took place.

522
00:30:33.239 --> 00:30:35.331
So you should see there it is,

523
00:30:35.331 --> 00:30:39.620
email character is a 100
character at this point.

524
00:30:39.620 --> 00:30:44.695
But now what I'm gonna do instead is I'm
gonna run this command that says look,

525
00:30:44.695 --> 00:30:50.096
on that column, I wanna change that to 50
characters instead, for the Data Type.

526
00:30:50.096 --> 00:30:51.960
I can actually, let me see.

527
00:30:53.540 --> 00:30:54.150
Guess what I did?

528
00:30:54.150 --> 00:30:56.725
I've added in an s at the end,
so that's why.

529
00:30:56.725 --> 00:30:59.830
[LAUGH] All right, let me run it again.

530
00:30:59.830 --> 00:31:00.660
There we go.

531
00:31:00.660 --> 00:31:02.220
Command completed successfully.

532
00:31:03.410 --> 00:31:08.860
Now if I go ahead and refresh, I just
like refreshing all the tables instead,

533
00:31:10.960 --> 00:31:14.720
and then NewEmployee2,
and I go to Columns.

534
00:31:14.720 --> 00:31:16.260
And now you can see, oops.

535
00:31:16.260 --> 00:31:20.390
Well, maybe if somebody were better
at navigating, you could see it.

536
00:31:21.890 --> 00:31:22.920
There you go.

537
00:31:22.920 --> 00:31:27.951
Notice that it just changed the entire
data type here, from 100 characters to

538
00:31:27.951 --> 00:31:32.770
the ID of 50 characters here instead,
gives you that ability, very quickly,

539
00:31:33.840 --> 00:31:38.900
very easily, if you needed that to match
another table at some point, some time.

540
00:31:38.900 --> 00:31:41.580
Now just at the end here we need
to talk about something but

541
00:31:41.580 --> 00:31:46.850
the problem is it will only run
on Enterprise Editions, okay?

542
00:31:46.850 --> 00:31:50.120
So the edition that I'm running is
Standard edition, it's not gonna work.

543
00:31:50.120 --> 00:31:53.232
And that is dealing with what
we call table compression, okay?

544
00:31:53.232 --> 00:31:55.464
Table compression essentially says look,

545
00:31:55.464 --> 00:31:59.322
before you start running a lot of this,
in storage space you want to compress

546
00:31:59.322 --> 00:32:02.112
everything down as much as
possible if you can, okay?

547
00:32:02.112 --> 00:32:04.910
Well, you can do the same thing here,
okay?

548
00:32:04.910 --> 00:32:08.540
But the problem is, like I said, with the
Standard, it's not gonna end up running.

549
00:32:08.540 --> 00:32:11.150
The only thing that you're doing
differently at the very beginning,

550
00:32:11.150 --> 00:32:16.170
when you create this, is you're adding
in one line, okay, which is with, and

551
00:32:16.170 --> 00:32:21.400
then the term data compression, and
it's actually row or page, okay?

552
00:32:21.400 --> 00:32:24.780
So, this is only gonna happen
with the Enterprise edition.

553
00:32:24.780 --> 00:32:28.540
You can do row level compression where
you take every single row of data and

554
00:32:28.540 --> 00:32:32.080
kind of squish another, take out all
the spaces and all the stuff here.

555
00:32:32.080 --> 00:32:34.070
Squish it in as tight as possible.

556
00:32:34.070 --> 00:32:35.880
Or you can do it by the page.

557
00:32:35.880 --> 00:32:38.560
Now, by the page is a little bit stranger,
right?

558
00:32:38.560 --> 00:32:42.270
Because what it's saying is actually take
the idea of a paging information and

559
00:32:42.270 --> 00:32:45.350
the file there and
kind of compress that out instead.

560
00:32:45.350 --> 00:32:49.790
So, it's all about, of course, performance
impact and benefit for us as well, and

561
00:32:49.790 --> 00:32:52.670
if you were to actually write that one,
you can do that as well,

562
00:32:52.670 --> 00:32:54.600
change that to the word page.

563
00:32:54.600 --> 00:32:58.090
But if you were running this on
an Enterprise edition instead, and

564
00:32:58.090 --> 00:33:00.560
you started off with row compression, and

565
00:33:00.560 --> 00:33:06.130
you wanted to change it to page
compression, you can do that as well.

566
00:33:06.130 --> 00:33:08.740
Now, the only thing that's
different about the row and

567
00:33:08.740 --> 00:33:12.180
the page level types of
compression is this.

568
00:33:12.180 --> 00:33:14.590
Row compression only does row compression.

569
00:33:14.590 --> 00:33:17.220
Page compression though
does row compression

570
00:33:17.220 --> 00:33:21.110
as well as the paging file type
of compression as well, okay.

571
00:33:21.110 --> 00:33:23.520
So, it actually does both for you.

572
00:33:23.520 --> 00:33:24.820
Is there a benefit to doing both?

573
00:33:24.820 --> 00:33:27.990
Well, yeah, there's always a benefit
to actually compressing data,

574
00:33:27.990 --> 00:33:30.870
making sure that you're actually
as compact as possible.

575
00:33:30.870 --> 00:33:33.480
But, overall though,
it really depends on what you need

576
00:33:33.480 --> 00:33:38.380
done at that particular point in time or
what the requirement actually is gonna be.

577
00:33:38.380 --> 00:33:41.860
So, just kind of remember here that
it's a fairly simple idea, but

578
00:33:41.860 --> 00:33:46.080
it's not gonna run if you try and actually
do this inside of the Standard edition.

579
00:33:46.080 --> 00:33:49.020
If I remember correctly because
I was trying to do this

580
00:33:49.020 --> 00:33:49.730
just a little bit earlier.

581
00:33:49.730 --> 00:33:52.410
Let me see if I can run this here,
and execute.

582
00:33:54.020 --> 00:34:00.430
It says to me here, it says, Cannot
enable compression for this new object

583
00:34:00.430 --> 00:34:06.080
that I created, only SQL Server Enterprise
Edition supports the compression.

584
00:34:06.080 --> 00:34:08.600
So if you're actually wondering,
if you try and run this and

585
00:34:08.600 --> 00:34:11.910
go hey, it's not working, it's more
than likely you're exactly like me here,

586
00:34:11.910 --> 00:34:13.780
you're running the Standard Edition of it.

587
00:34:13.780 --> 00:34:18.540
But you do need to pay attention to that
idea and understand that there's row and

588
00:34:18.540 --> 00:34:21.240
that there's page compression
that you may have to deal with.

589
00:34:21.240 --> 00:34:24.660
And remember that page actually does both,
row only does row.

590
00:34:24.660 --> 00:34:27.490
So, some of the things that will
help you out when you start creating

591
00:34:27.490 --> 00:34:31.260
the tables here and getting everything
compressed down the way that you want to,

592
00:34:31.260 --> 00:34:35.160
as well as understanding the two ways
that you can create the tables here.

593
00:34:35.160 --> 00:34:38.890
Either creating it with the definition
already there or creating it where you

594
00:34:38.890 --> 00:34:43.850
actually go ahead and you actually
add the data in at the same time, and

595
00:34:43.850 --> 00:34:47.500
you're left with whatever the defaults
are when you actually add that data in.

596
00:34:47.500 --> 00:34:49.410
And then of course being able to alter or

597
00:34:49.410 --> 00:34:53.800
modify by changing or
adding in a couple of different columns.

598
00:34:53.800 --> 00:34:58.624
It really does help you out when you start
creating tables inside of SQL Server 2014.

599
00:34:58.624 --> 00:35:00.366
>> In this episode we've been looking at,

600
00:35:00.366 --> 00:35:02.376
just like Ronnie said,
how to create tables.

601
00:35:02.376 --> 00:35:05.921
And keep Ronnie's advice on hand because
I've taken some of these Microsoft

602
00:35:05.921 --> 00:35:08.697
exams and I can tell you the one
way that is the easiest way to do

603
00:35:08.697 --> 00:35:10.625
won't be the way they ask you on the exam.

604
00:35:10.625 --> 00:35:11.745
So know your syntax.

605
00:35:11.745 --> 00:35:12.985
Ronnie, thank you for that information.

606
00:35:12.985 --> 00:35:14.555
Do you have anything else for
us in this one?

607
00:35:14.555 --> 00:35:16.775
>> Well, the only other thing is practice.

608
00:35:16.775 --> 00:35:19.895
That's the only thing that's gonna help
you to get better at this is to continue

609
00:35:19.895 --> 00:35:21.110
to practice.

610
00:35:21.110 --> 00:35:22.540
Add those things in there,

611
00:35:22.540 --> 00:35:26.600
remove them, make sure you start
using these commands more regularly.

612
00:35:26.600 --> 00:35:27.480
On the exam,

613
00:35:27.480 --> 00:35:31.570
identifying which of the commands is
absolutely gonna work is gonna be key for

614
00:35:31.570 --> 00:35:36.730
us when we get ready to take that exam and
which one absolutely won't work, as well.

615
00:35:36.730 --> 00:35:40.140
But data types, especially in this one,
are very important, so

616
00:35:40.140 --> 00:35:43.000
make sure you pay attention
to those data types as well.

617
00:35:43.000 --> 00:35:45.880
>> All right Ronnie, as always we
appreciate you joining us here, and

618
00:35:45.880 --> 00:35:48.860
we appreciate you the viewers joining
us too, but we're gonna go ahead and

619
00:35:48.860 --> 00:35:50.480
sign out for ITPRO.TV.

620
00:35:50.480 --> 00:35:51.810
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

621
00:35:51.810 --> 00:35:52.583
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

622
00:35:52.583 --> 00:35:55.097
>> And we'll see you next time.

623
00:35:55.097 --> 00:36:02.400
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie explain how to restrict the information presented to a user or application by creating views. They also demonstrate how to the a view that has already been created.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Views
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.288 --> 00:00:14.051
Welcome back to another exciting episode.

3
00:00:14.051 --> 00:00:16.370
Here at IT Pro TV,
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.370 --> 00:00:19.560
And in today's episode we're
moving through more of querying

5
00:00:19.560 --> 00:00:20.820
Microsoft's Sequel Server 2014.

6
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:24.040
And we've got none other than Mr.
Ronny Wong with us today.

7
00:00:24.040 --> 00:00:25.260
Ronny, how are you doing today sir?

8
00:00:25.260 --> 00:00:29.510
>> I am doing great as we continue on our
journey taking us through some more about.

9
00:00:29.510 --> 00:00:33.010
Creating some different objects that we
have to create inside of our database.

10
00:00:33.010 --> 00:00:36.220
And we've taken look at basic table
creation already in the series.

11
00:00:36.220 --> 00:00:39.850
So, make sure you check that
particular episode out, as well.

12
00:00:39.850 --> 00:00:43.340
And we also talked a lot about
querying in our series as well.

13
00:00:43.340 --> 00:00:48.235
Now, for us, when we start to go a little
bit more and a little bit deeper into what

14
00:00:48.235 --> 00:00:52.110
we need, we actually have to take
a look at something that we call views,

15
00:00:52.110 --> 00:00:53.600
is what we have to take a look at.

16
00:00:53.600 --> 00:00:58.135
Now just like it sounds, it actually
gives us a view into our database.

17
00:00:58.135 --> 00:01:01.520
Well, this is a very helpful
element that we can add in that

18
00:01:01.520 --> 00:01:04.360
it becomes an object
inside of our database.

19
00:01:04.360 --> 00:01:08.030
That we can actually use very easily and
very readily and

20
00:01:08.030 --> 00:01:12.760
you might be asking yourself, okay,
why is it so important that we do this?

21
00:01:12.760 --> 00:01:16.446
Well if you think about the idea
of a simple query that you and

22
00:01:16.446 --> 00:01:21.166
I actually can end up running inside of
my SQL database or in your SQL database

23
00:01:21.166 --> 00:01:26.610
think about what's actually being exposed
at that particular point in time.

24
00:01:26.610 --> 00:01:30.970
The majority of that exposure, is when you
write some type of select statement and

25
00:01:30.970 --> 00:01:35.130
the from, you're actually accessing right,

26
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:39.180
the data that exists on those base tables,
right?

27
00:01:39.180 --> 00:01:44.550
The actual logical structures,
where the data absolutely exists.

28
00:01:44.550 --> 00:01:48.940
Now when we start thinking about that,
a lot of times, when we have other things

29
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:52.795
besides people like me, writing
queries such as report writers right.

30
00:01:52.795 --> 00:01:57.180
You might also then have
applications that connect in and

31
00:01:57.180 --> 00:02:00.250
get information out of
that database as well.

32
00:02:00.250 --> 00:02:04.340
And so there's a lot of different ways
that we can connect and get that data.

33
00:02:04.340 --> 00:02:07.160
And there's actually some other things
that can happen when we actually

34
00:02:07.160 --> 00:02:08.540
access the data directly too.

35
00:02:08.540 --> 00:02:12.340
>> You know Ronnie, I'm thinking
security kind of mindset here,

36
00:02:12.340 --> 00:02:15.360
if you are giving somebody
a view to a database.

37
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:18.250
Now that sounds like it could
be a security risk that

38
00:02:18.250 --> 00:02:21.040
I'm giving you access and
you can see what's in my database,

39
00:02:21.040 --> 00:02:24.900
and we know we're talking
about a relational database.

40
00:02:24.900 --> 00:02:27.800
And all those relations behind the scenes,
now is that something that can

41
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:30.380
happen if you do
>> have somebody generate a query, and

42
00:02:30.380 --> 00:02:34.360
it returns information, could it give them
access to maybe too much information?

43
00:02:34.360 --> 00:02:35.160
>> It really can,

44
00:02:35.160 --> 00:02:39.550
especially if they're accessing those
base database tables directly, right.

45
00:02:39.550 --> 00:02:42.880
So if you're actually exposing it to
where somebody can write a query, or

46
00:02:42.880 --> 00:02:46.460
an application can write a query,
directly to those tables.

47
00:02:46.460 --> 00:02:50.420
It also may mean, even with a little
bit of modification of permissions,

48
00:02:50.420 --> 00:02:54.270
unauthorized access as well, that what
can happen is they can go and they can

49
00:02:54.270 --> 00:02:59.640
modify the data and the weird thing is
it's directly modifying the data itself.

50
00:02:59.640 --> 00:03:04.710
So what you and I generally want to do
instead is to create what we call views

51
00:03:04.710 --> 00:03:08.840
that will essentially show them
the view of the data base in the way

52
00:03:08.840 --> 00:03:13.480
that we want them to be able to see it and
access it on, you know, instead.

53
00:03:13.480 --> 00:03:16.720
Now this is actually very important
because of what it really does

54
00:03:16.720 --> 00:03:17.770
create for us.

55
00:03:17.770 --> 00:03:20.160
It essentially gives us a limitation,

56
00:03:20.160 --> 00:03:23.260
it allows us to say here's
what these people need.

57
00:03:23.260 --> 00:03:25.340
Here's what this application needs.

58
00:03:25.340 --> 00:03:28.470
Not exposure to the entirety
of the database but

59
00:03:28.470 --> 00:03:32.980
only to the columns, or
the technical term, the fields,

60
00:03:32.980 --> 00:03:37.390
that we want them to be able to access and
to be able to pull all the information in.

61
00:03:37.390 --> 00:03:42.040
So that way, when they go and they try and
connect in through this view, well they're

62
00:03:42.040 --> 00:03:47.800
only given a very limited access depending
on the view that you end up creating.

00:30:59.850 --> 00:31:03.590
elements that we have to
actually be able to do this.

507
00:31:03.590 --> 00:31:07.260
Now, does it actually
impact performance any.

508
00:31:07.260 --> 00:31:08.610
Well, if you think about it,

509
00:31:08.610 --> 00:31:12.870
it actually impacts performance for
at least the application is connecting

510
00:31:12.870 --> 00:31:16.230
in just a little bit cuz they're
only really accessing this view.

511
00:31:16.230 --> 00:31:17.594
But in the background though,

512
00:31:17.594 --> 00:31:20.644
remember there is actually still
all of the schema infrastructure.

513
00:31:20.644 --> 00:31:24.090
And that select statement is still
being run in the background but

514
00:31:24.090 --> 00:31:27.380
now nobody actually sees what
that select statement is.

515
00:31:27.380 --> 00:31:30.110
The only thing that you are doing is
your querying against what the data

516
00:31:30.110 --> 00:31:31.910
is actually supposed to pull in here.

517
00:31:31.910 --> 00:31:35.880
And you're only gonna get access to
that and not the entirety of everything.

518
00:31:35.880 --> 00:31:39.537
We do have a few other things that
we actually have to talk about,

519
00:31:39.537 --> 00:31:43.482
but overall though, for us in terms
of creating and altering a view.

520
00:31:43.482 --> 00:31:45.594
Well, this is actually the heart and
soul of it,

521
00:31:45.594 --> 00:31:47.610
is to be able to do
something just like this.

522
00:31:47.610 --> 00:31:50.740
>> That's great, being able to put
that information behind the glass and

523
00:31:50.740 --> 00:31:51.820
locked display case.

524
00:31:51.820 --> 00:31:55.249
So only displaying the information
that you want them to have access to.

525
00:31:55.249 --> 00:31:57.750
Ronnie, thanks for
all that good information.

526
00:31:57.750 --> 00:32:00.530
I know we're gonna come back with
a part two because we've got plenty of

527
00:32:00.530 --> 00:32:02.530
more good information to go.

528
00:32:02.530 --> 00:32:05.950
So, Ronnie, got any parting words for
this episode?

529
00:32:05.950 --> 00:32:09.900
>> Well, just try, so that's the key.

530
00:32:09.900 --> 00:32:14.970
And remember the syntax, itself,
is also key, especially for the exam.

531
00:32:14.970 --> 00:32:19.270
And take a look at that
syntax especially closely and

532
00:32:19.270 --> 00:32:21.630
also of course those error messages too.

533
00:32:21.630 --> 00:32:24.070
Do not put it past them
on the exam to say,

534
00:32:24.070 --> 00:32:27.540
the error message indicates which
of the following didn't happen?

535
00:32:27.540 --> 00:32:30.925
And it's very easy to overlook,
so make sure you pay attention.

536
00:32:30.925 --> 00:32:32.365
Attend to those error messages.

537
00:32:32.365 --> 00:32:36.245
See if it really helps you out as well,
but practice is pretty much the key here

538
00:32:36.245 --> 00:32:40.335
in getting used to working inside of
that database and feeling comfortable.

539
00:32:40.335 --> 00:32:43.825
When you read through those select
queries of what's actually gonna happen

540
00:32:43.825 --> 00:32:45.485
line by line as you actually take it.

541
00:32:45.485 --> 00:32:46.595
So just remember that.

542
00:32:46.595 --> 00:32:48.726
>> Ronnie thank you that looks
like a good place to wrap up.

543
00:32:48.726 --> 00:32:51.791
So we're gonna go ahead and
take the time to sign out here at ITProTV.

544
00:32:51.791 --> 00:32:53.075
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

545
00:32:53.075 --> 00:32:53.933
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

546
00:32:53.933 --> 00:32:55.234
>> And we'll see you next time.

547
00:32:55.234 --> 00:33:01.463

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their discussion on restricting the information presented to users or applications. They using the inline table-valued function as well as creating indexed views to optimize performance. They also talk about how to ensure that the database doesnt break.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Views Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2

That's right, this is a part two

How are you doing Ronnie?

on to take a look at more of

We're specifically talking about,
of course, the idea of creating views and,

And, there's a couple of other things

Remember that for us views really do

other people to be able to see or

But, it also helps us out as

We instead can give them

Now, when we create the idea of views,

There's also one other

And then, we'll talk about a couple of

And then,

So, let's go ahead and

Now, of course, inside of SQL Server.

It really did.

It has tried to actually make

So, of course, though in the true,

View, excuse me, if we need to

DROP VIEW, and

Now, we've actually used functions

Make an aggregate of it,

ID, first name, last name,

So, that is function.

I simply took the order date

And, I told it just report to me

time function of the ordered day

00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:54.610
Now, if you're trying to say, okay so,

what makes that different from what you're

Well, in both of these,

The same thing with the SUM.

It actually ends up reporting that one

It's actually taking that and giving us

The inline table type of function

So, when we start to take a look at this

instead, the result of this

Now, normally we can actually

So, as an alternative or

So that when we go ahead and query,

00:07:36.610 --> 00:07:39.730
It actually allows us to essentially
allows us to replace all those

00:07:39.730 --> 00:07:42.870

00:07:42.870 --> 00:07:46.500
So, when we start seeing this

Well, it actually allows us to

It actually becomes the source of

Tables will again do the same thing but
for us here the function is a little bit

00:08:12.040 --> 00:08:14.430
more efficient in the very fact
that it's generating it and

145
00:08:14.430 --> 00:08:16.240
is storing it in that way.

146
00:08:16.240 --> 00:08:18.460
So the good thing is
the functions can be stored and

147
00:08:18.460 --> 00:08:20.340
then reused whenever we need them.

148
00:08:20.340 --> 00:08:22.920
And need them to actually
be reused as well.

149
00:08:22.920 --> 00:08:24.290
Okay.
So

00:08:24.290 --> 00:08:28.500
they really do become
a nice little difference.

151
00:08:28.500 --> 00:08:29.070
Right.

152
00:08:29.070 --> 00:08:33.170
An alternative to some of the ways
that things we actually have here

00:08:33.170 --> 00:08:35.130

154
00:08:35.130 --> 00:08:35.870
Okay.

So the easiest thing of course
is to take a look here and

let's go ahead and

00:08:42.300 --> 00:08:47.280
Now this one adds in a little

00:08:47.280 --> 00:08:50.720
And the create view is really
two lines that it added in

00:08:50.720 --> 00:08:52.530
if you remember in the create view, right.

00:08:52.530 --> 00:08:56.540
We had create view and then the second

162
00:09:00.200 --> 00:09:03.490
Now some of those other elements that
are like with the there was one that was

called with encryption and
I did forget to mention this so

this is a great place for
me to mention this as well.

165
00:09:09.100 --> 00:09:14.340
Inside of Server 2012, 2016 you might
see if I would have run that one and

00:09:14.340 --> 00:09:16.500
that's why I chose also not to run it.

167
00:09:16.500 --> 00:09:20.490
Is that, it might tell you that, hey, you
don't get the encryption if you don't have

00:09:20.490 --> 00:09:24.050
the enterprise addition, and
I'm running the standard edition of this.

169
00:09:24.050 --> 00:09:26.190
So, you might actually
see something like that.

00:09:26.190 --> 00:09:29.900
But, for us here, it actually does
get just a little bit more complex.

00:09:29.900 --> 00:09:34.830
Now, it doesn't have to get super complex,
but it's a little bit more here.

172
00:09:34.830 --> 00:09:39.380
First and foremost we begin with
the idea of create function, okay?

00:09:39.380 --> 00:09:43.200
So not exactly a very difficult syntax,
and

then we need to to provide it

175
00:09:46.710 --> 00:09:50.650
Now on this one function is
normally represented by 'fn' as

00:09:50.650 --> 00:09:53.170
far as a standard type of abbreviation.

177
00:09:53.170 --> 00:09:54.260
And I like going ahead and

putting that in front of anything that

179
00:09:57.580 --> 00:09:58.820
Now, do you have to?

Nope, you don't have to at all,

Excuse me if I can't say that.

And we definitely appreciate

But we're gonna go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie take a look a ways to maintain consistency within a database by using constraints. They discuss primary key constraints with demonstrations on how to implement them. They will also explore using foreign key constraints while demonstrating their implementation.
episodes.title: Create and Modify Constraints

So the good solid foundation that you've

Not really ok?

Of each of the rows in

So, if you actually had

Well, we need a column in the database

And, even though you and

Even though you and I can choose that,

They can have whatever name they want.

In fact, it could be 15 John Smiths

You're saying that there is

Is it something like that,

00:09:35.340 --> 00:09:36.170
>> It really is.

When it comes down to it,
what you're talking about,

there is of course the active

00:09:41.053 --> 00:09:44.333
Well, if you think about it, the term that
I just used even if we don't call it that,

00:09:45.966 --> 00:09:50.574
It is an Active Directory database, so
what active directory does is it says

00:09:50.574 --> 00:09:55.820

by putting this information in there.

178
00:09:55.820 --> 00:09:59.024
And in the background it's actually
generating some type of GUI

179
00:09:59.024 --> 00:09:59.924
actually an SID.

180
00:09:59.924 --> 00:10:03.301
That is what's generated but it's really
a GUI in the background really putting

181

182
00:10:06.295 --> 00:10:10.990
But in the same way in database entries
usually, especially a relational database.

183
00:10:10.990 --> 00:10:15.130
Every single table that we add
into that entire database,

184
00:10:15.130 --> 00:10:17.690
they're like the Adventure Works
2012 database.

Every single table is gonna probably
need to have what we call a primary

key value added in.

00:10:23.380 --> 00:10:28.380
So if I wanna add in additional

I am also going to need to go ahead and

let's go ahead and

00:10:35.830 --> 00:10:38.700
First and foremost,
what we're going to take a look at and

00:10:38.700 --> 00:10:43.180
do for right now, is we're just
gonna create a basic table here,

00:10:43.180 --> 00:10:48.610
okay, that goes ahead and

00:10:48.610 --> 00:10:53.490
So if I take a look at this situation

00:10:53.490 --> 00:10:56.700
so the good thing is we already

00:10:56.700 --> 00:11:01.030
We go ahead and we use a create table

And then inside of a set of parenthesis,

I need to make sure that I declare

not this thing can be a null value or

Now, the other thing that we can also do

Notice the placement of it,

That's just where I chose to place it but

look at what it says here

00:11:39.560 --> 00:11:42.680
Here's the constraint, and
I'm going to give it a name,

I'm just gonna call it PK_Cat.

Now, do you have to do that?

No, you can call it whatever you want to,

00:11:47.674 --> 00:11:49.400
But I'm gonna go ahead and say,

the primary key is gonna be
generated as a unique key here.

And it's actually going to go ahead and

So we can do something like that.

00:19:05.850 --> 00:19:06.400
Okay?

327
00:19:06.400 --> 00:19:12.100
And we could put no sale if we wanted,
to or no amount yet, or none reported,

or whatever it might be, a zero might be

And that's the key here,
is the default that we're left with.

00:19:18.988 --> 00:19:20.249
>> So the default constraint,

00:19:20.249 --> 00:19:23.086
it can potentially save you some

that you'll have to do to be able to

>> Right, and that's what we really want

So instead, you might see that, a kind of
a b something that you have to deal with.

335
00:19:34.960 --> 00:19:36.494
So, let's take a look here and

336

hopefully this will also help clear it up

337

338

So, let's take a look here, okay?

339
00:19:45.320 --> 00:19:47.890
So, we're gonna create this table and

00:19:47.890 --> 00:19:53.030
take care by using the default

341
00:19:53.030 --> 00:19:55.380
So I'm hoping that the explanation,
as we walk through here,

342
00:19:55.380 --> 00:19:57.480
helps us out a little bit more.

343
00:19:57.480 --> 00:19:59.930
So, we're gonna create a new table and

00:19:59.930 --> 00:20:05.040
I already have a products table, but

00:20:05.040 --> 00:20:07.060
So, my product ID here

00:20:07.060 --> 00:20:11.600
I'm gonna make sure it's not a null,
and this is gonna be a prime one for

00:20:11.600 --> 00:20:12.700
a primary key.

00:20:12.700 --> 00:20:15.167
So that's why I also added an identity,

349

Product name, fifty characters long,
this one cannot be a null.

350

Supplier ID,

Category ID,

Unit price, I wanna make sure that's

00:20:27.943 --> 00:20:31.090
or data type, and that one's not a null.

00:20:31.090 --> 00:20:35.830
But, what if we don't know how much it

355
00:20:35.830 --> 00:20:40.400
So even if I have products, it could

actually costs as far as

00:20:44.520 --> 00:20:47.590
So now, notice that what I'm doing, okay,

00:20:47.590 --> 00:20:49.960
because I'm telling it that I

00:20:49.960 --> 00:20:53.030
I don't want there to be a possibility

360
00:20:53.030 --> 00:20:54.710
I'm gonna add in this constraint.

00:20:54.710 --> 00:20:58.790
And now you see another prefix here, DFT.

00:20:58.790 --> 00:21:02.370
Now, I actually added in the T in there

363
00:21:02.370 --> 00:21:05.950
But we saw it a little bit earlier

00:21:05.950 --> 00:21:09.380
that you also normally see

00:21:09.380 --> 00:21:13.280
So I like adding in the T cuz it just

00:21:13.280 --> 00:21:15.050
Then I'm gonna do it on this unit price.

00:21:15.050 --> 00:21:17.650
And now, notice what I can declare.

I can declare what that

Now, that doesn't mean that

00:21:25.440 --> 00:21:28.624
In other words, if you don't

00:21:29.680 --> 00:21:32.320
So that's why it's called

00:21:34.580 --> 00:21:36.480
Now, we can do this with

00:21:43.590 --> 00:21:45.490

00:21:48.680 --> 00:21:52.300

00:21:54.650 --> 00:21:57.030
So instead,

00:21:57.030 --> 00:21:59.648
And I'm gonna tell it, hey,

00:21:59.648 --> 00:22:01.426
So that makes sense, right, the 0?

384
00:22:01.426 --> 00:22:03.606
Let me see if I can make that

385
00:22:03.606 --> 00:22:04.610
There we go.

386
00:22:04.610 --> 00:22:08.380
Okay, a 0's actually meaning

387
00:22:08.380 --> 00:22:10.980
So I wanna just make sure
that I report something

00:22:10.980 --> 00:22:15.850
if we are actually going to end up

389
00:22:15.850 --> 00:22:20.860
So that way, we don't have the idea
of null is just interspersed.

390
00:22:20.860 --> 00:22:22.980
Because I didn't know what else to do.

391
00:22:22.980 --> 00:22:24.420
I can now say that.

392
00:22:24.420 --> 00:22:27.100
So you can again, like I said,

00:22:27.100 --> 00:22:28.678
You can change those numbers.

00:22:28.678 --> 00:22:30.118
Usually the key here if you do it,

00:22:30.118 --> 00:22:34.130
is to make sure that you change it to

00:22:34.130 --> 00:22:38.520
So for example, MONEY here,
that's not a great one for

00:22:38.520 --> 00:22:43.108
me to put no value as far as

398
00:22:43.108 --> 00:22:46.622
But at the same time,
I think you could do it if you wanted to.

399
00:22:46.622 --> 00:22:49.967
I'm not gonna try it for right now, but
I think you could but a lot of times what

00:22:49.967 --> 00:22:53.078
that means is you have to convert it

401
00:22:53.078 --> 00:22:56.820
But you don't want to actually get

00:22:56.820 --> 00:23:01.090
So usually, you're keeping the same

403
00:23:01.090 --> 00:23:06.340
So in this sense, that's what we can end
up doing so let's go ahead and run this.

00:23:06.340 --> 00:23:07.970
Let me make sure that
I'm only running that.

00:23:10.160 --> 00:23:13.240
So I'm gonna highlight

And execute it.

407
00:23:14.320 --> 00:23:18.830
And now, it's actually telling me I

00:23:18.830 --> 00:23:22.300
For the definition of table.

409
00:23:22.300 --> 00:23:23.979
All right, well, let's see here.

00:23:23.979 --> 00:23:25.250
See what I did wrong.

00:23:26.650 --> 00:23:29.310
All right, so I found out what

00:23:29.310 --> 00:23:31.212
I went overboard on the commas, okay?

00:23:31.212 --> 00:23:33.708
And with that,

00:23:33.708 --> 00:23:35.570
because that's where

00:23:35.570 --> 00:23:37.720
It's essentially saying I'm looking for

00:23:37.720 --> 00:23:40.978
I don't know what you wanna link to, so

00:23:40.978 --> 00:23:44.600
So that's what I'm gonna do here and

00:23:44.600 --> 00:23:48.471
And so now when we run this entirety here,
it should run and

00:23:48.471 --> 00:23:52.588

00:23:52.588 --> 00:23:56.598
So now when I do that, and it doesn't

00:23:56.598 --> 00:24:02.957
But if I were to do a simple SELECT

I'm about to type in categories,

00:24:12.641 --> 00:24:14.190

00:24:14.190 --> 00:24:15.924
Well now, it actually does show up.

00:24:15.924 --> 00:24:19.316
But if I had data in there,

The bit's not gonna show up, but the ID

00:24:32.119 --> 00:24:35.388

And setting up these constraints is

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate how to create and alter DML Triggers in SQL 2014. The start by explaining the particulars of DML Triggers; the when/where/why/how they are used. Then they take a look at the AFTER trigger type followed by the INSTEAD OF trigger type. Finally, they explore nested triggers and how to use the UPDATE function.
episodes.title: Create and Alter DML Triggers

Now when it comes down to triggers, this

In other words, we wanna make sure

If we do instead of delete,
we're gonna use the deleted table instead.

493
00:27:03.598 --> 00:27:08.560
And it's harder to use those words and
the statement at the same time.

494
00:27:08.560 --> 00:27:10.540
But yeah, normally we're
actually using one or the other.

495
00:27:10.540 --> 00:27:13.400
But those two are actually in
the background of what's actually in

496
00:27:13.400 --> 00:27:16.290
the SQL Server to help us out.

497
00:27:16.290 --> 00:27:20.200
Kind of understand that there's a lot
more going on than what you think.

498
00:27:20.200 --> 00:27:22.420
So, as easy as a statement seems and

499
00:27:22.420 --> 00:27:26.760
hopefully the logic seems the same if
you've ever been working inside of SQL.

500
00:27:26.760 --> 00:27:29.635
It's not very difficult as far as
anything else that we've added in,

00:27:29.635 --> 00:27:32.325
we've just added in

00:27:32.325 --> 00:27:36.215
But the SQL query was still there,
that we've actually done before and

00:27:36.215 --> 00:27:38.665
all we've done is we've said
we're gonna create a trigger.

00:27:38.665 --> 00:27:41.005

a delete or

00:27:45.160 --> 00:27:49.040
So both these are very powerful ways that

As well as enforcing some of

00:27:52.570 --> 00:27:57.550
And these are actually good enforcements

00:27:57.550 --> 00:28:00.040
It just says when you run the coding,
watch for it and

00:28:00.040 --> 00:28:02.220

00:28:02.220 --> 00:28:04.720
So there's a lot of information
that's right there for

00:28:04.720 --> 00:28:07.760
us to actually be ready to
be able to use as well.

00:28:07.760 --> 00:28:10.150
Now, the other thing that we also have,

Everything that I've done is really about

If I wanna do this with multiple columns,

Yes, you can actually do it with

Let me show you this too, okay?

So at this particular point here,

And so everything I've showed you,

I don't wanna say it's complex,

But I did wanna show you that you

So I can create a trigger and this

00:28:40.720 --> 00:28:43.250

That if you actually update either

So if this happens and there's some

So if I wanted to, I could do that.

Let me go ahead and

00:29:12.460 --> 00:29:15.880
See, I had already created this one and

I was getting a little

00:29:29.348 --> 00:29:33.065
All right, so if I do that and

00:29:33.065 --> 00:29:35.821
I'm gonna update that Person.Address and

I'm gonna set the PostalCode to this,

00:29:41.690 --> 00:29:42.900
So, if I go ahead and

00:29:42.900 --> 00:29:48.400

00:29:48.400 --> 00:29:52.190
And let me see if I can zoom in on those

00:29:52.190 --> 00:29:55.617
So remember I typed in 50,009,

00:29:55.617 --> 00:29:57.420
I can define that myself.

00:29:57.420 --> 00:29:59.460

00:29:59.460 --> 00:30:01.320

00:30:04.430 --> 00:30:08.170
But notice because I didn't define them,

So, you can actually set all that stuff up

00:30:16.180 --> 00:30:18.182
Now can you do this even with functions?

Yes, there's some other ones

And you can even do that

You can continue to nest triggers, okay?

No, okay?

>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz you really have to follow the logic

But in our example, being sure that you

Making sure that you understand when

And also of course, realizing that if you

If you try and actually run that

It just says I'm not gonna do

So always drop that trigger or

572

00:31:10.760 --> 00:31:13.660
But those are kind of the key

00:31:14.790 --> 00:31:16.140
The majority that's like I said,

So if you understand stored procedures,

And if you're going well, I don't

And that will actually help you out a

Because this is a subcategory

583

>> All right, Ronnie, well,

Increasing our SQL knowledge and

00:31:47.130 --> 00:31:50.870
That being said, looks like we've run

00:31:50.870 --> 00:31:53.230
just perfectly too,
I mean you hit it right on the nose.

So kudos to Ryan today.

Again, thanks for dropping by.

00:31:56.070 --> 00:31:59.740
We thank you for watching, signing off for

00:31:59.740 --> 00:32:00.300
Daniel Lowrie.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie start their exposition of the SELECT SQL query. They start by showing you how to perform a simple SELECT query to find set data from a database. Then they pair down the results by using the WHERE and GROUP BY filter statements.
episodes.title: Basic SELECT Queries

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe how to use the JOINs function to return data from multiple databases. They begin by looking at the traditional way to query data from multiple databases and then how to use the INNER JOIN command to filter that data down. Then they show you the LEFT JOIN and RIGHT JOIN commands to return data sets that have matching values as well as all values from either the right or left tables respectively.
episodes.title: Query Using JOINS

So, let's take for example,

00:33:22.110 --> 00:33:24.720
Yeah, that's the key is
trying to figure that out.

583
00:33:24.720 --> 00:33:29.380
Well, one of the things, of course, that
is recommended then is to use aliases.

584
00:33:29.380 --> 00:33:33.460
Now, this is not exactly the same query.

585
00:33:33.460 --> 00:33:35.050
But it's close.

586
00:33:35.050 --> 00:33:37.240
I did it just a little bit differently,
but

587
00:33:37.240 --> 00:33:41.440
notice how kind of neat this
one actually looks too.

588
00:33:41.440 --> 00:33:47.760
Much smaller, a couple of lines here
compared to this thing that essentially,

589
00:33:47.760 --> 00:33:49.100
that's pretty darn big.

590
00:33:49.100 --> 00:33:51.500
It takes up just about
that whole screen there.

591
00:33:51.500 --> 00:33:53.170
This one's a little bit less.

592
00:33:54.990 --> 00:33:59.100
And now you can see there's the name for
the department, first and

593
00:33:59.100 --> 00:34:03.110
last name, and
the actual job title that that person has.

594
00:34:03.110 --> 00:34:05.720
We can actually select that one.

595
00:34:05.720 --> 00:34:09.240
And now, because I've used all those
aliases that we've talked about,

596
00:34:09.240 --> 00:34:11.880
using the as instead, it shortens it up.

597
00:34:11.880 --> 00:34:17.300
And now, when I run and I execute that,
I can still see the same 18 rows here, but

598
00:34:17.300 --> 00:34:20.870
now I've also added in job
title at the end, as well.

599
00:34:20.870 --> 00:34:21.710
So you can see, everybody,

600
00:34:21.710 --> 00:34:26.050
there's actually a part that
has the word sales in it, too.

601
00:34:26.050 --> 00:34:29.230
So when you see something like that,
you might be saying, or no excuse me,

602
00:34:29.230 --> 00:34:31.763
the name of the department is sales and
then the job titles.

603
00:34:31.763 --> 00:34:35.130
They just all happen to, of course,
to have the word sales in it as well.

604
00:34:35.130 --> 00:34:38.081
So that way you can actually see that
there's a couple of different things that

605
00:34:38.081 --> 00:34:39.900
will help you out in terms of the joints.

606
00:34:39.900 --> 00:34:43.120
Now does it take a little while
to work with the aliases?

607
00:34:43.120 --> 00:34:44.838
Yes, until you feel comfortable with them.

608
00:34:44.838 --> 00:34:50.410
But overall though, being able to actually
create an inner join is kind of one

609
00:34:50.410 --> 00:34:53.180
of the first things that we
have to be used to doing.

610
00:34:53.180 --> 00:34:54.700
Because more than likely,

611
00:34:54.700 --> 00:34:58.340
as far as your databases go in
the real production environment,

612
00:34:58.340 --> 00:35:01.090
I doubt there's gonna be a time you're
not going to be doing the join.

613
00:35:01.090 --> 00:35:02.290
I really do.

614
00:35:02.290 --> 00:35:05.613
So getting that stuff right,
understanding the logic behind it,

615
00:35:05.613 --> 00:35:09.607
trying to figure out those relationships,
and that single column in between.

616
00:35:09.607 --> 00:35:11.972
That is gonna be key for
you to be able to do this, and

617
00:35:11.972 --> 00:35:14.942
actually start becoming much
more efficient at writing joins,

618
00:35:14.942 --> 00:35:17.988
especially when you're actually
querying more than one table.

619
00:35:17.988 --> 00:35:21.150
>> All right Ronnie, well thanks so
much for stopping by and

620
00:35:21.150 --> 00:35:25.930
heaping more knowledge onto
our SQL querying toolkit,

621
00:35:25.930 --> 00:35:29.160
as it were, as we build up and
get better at doing this.

622
00:35:29.160 --> 00:35:32.010
And the joins is something interesting for

623
00:35:32.010 --> 00:35:34.685
us, work with multiple
different databases.

624
00:35:34.685 --> 00:35:38.010
Pulling some of the data
sets that we need, and

625
00:35:38.010 --> 00:35:40.870
then filter down to only exactly
what it is we're looking for.

626
00:35:40.870 --> 00:35:45.510
Cuz that's always fun to get those 9,000
million different tables that we get back,

627
00:35:45.510 --> 00:35:46.840
or rows and columns.

628
00:35:46.840 --> 00:35:48.380
That's not a good time had by anyone, but

629
00:35:48.380 --> 00:35:50.320
I know you got a little more
information for us to go.

630
00:35:50.320 --> 00:35:53.782
So there will be a part two to this,
so definitely drop by and

631
00:35:53.782 --> 00:35:55.210
have a look at that.

632
00:35:55.210 --> 00:35:56.650
Ronnie, we look forward
to seeing you there and

633
00:35:56.650 --> 00:35:58.190
we look forward to seeing
you there as well.

634
00:35:58.190 --> 00:36:01.250
As for this episode, we're gonna go
ahead and sign off, for ItProTV,

635
00:36:01.250 --> 00:36:02.895
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

636
00:36:02.895 --> 00:36:03.642
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

637
00:36:03.642 --> 00:36:04.495
>> We'll see you next time.

638
00:36:04.495 --> 00:36:13.290
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the concept and use of Temporary Tables, Views, and Derived Tables. They start by showing you how to use the Temporary Tables and Views and while both can be beneficial, also have their problems. Then they jump into the use of Derived Tables which are more efficient than using Temp Tables.
episodes.title: Query Using JOINS Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.148 --> 00:00:10.148
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.142 --> 00:00:17.180
All right, greeting everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.180 --> 00:00:20.021
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode we

4
00:00:20.021 --> 00:00:24.603
are continuing forward with our series on
querying the Microsoft SQL Server 2014.

5
00:00:24.603 --> 00:00:27.143
And joining us back in
the studio again today for

6
00:00:27.143 --> 00:00:31.207
part two on some very interesting ways
in which we can query our SQL servers,

7
00:00:31.207 --> 00:00:33.200
is our good friend Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:33.200 --> 00:00:33.862
Ronnie, welcome back, sir.

9
00:00:33.862 --> 00:00:34.511
How's it going today?

10
00:00:34.511 --> 00:00:37.207
>> Well, thank you for
having me back on the show, and

11
00:00:37.207 --> 00:00:41.727
it's going very well as we continue on our
journey here, and expanding our knowledge

12
00:00:41.727 --> 00:00:47.110
in terms of SQL 2014, and of course also
T-SQL as well, our Transact-SQL knowledge.

13
00:00:47.110 --> 00:00:51.852
So that we can actually make fairly
complex types of queries that we need to.

14
00:00:51.852 --> 00:00:55.713
Now remember that so far in our series we
have already taken a look at just simple

15
00:00:55.713 --> 00:00:59.652
select statements, pulling information
from a single table in our database.

16
00:00:59.652 --> 00:01:04.019
And then in a previous episode which I
think is actually the part one to this

17
00:01:04.019 --> 00:01:07.260
episode, we also took a look
at the beginnings here and

18
00:01:07.260 --> 00:01:12.051
the foundations of now beginning to query
what multiple tables at the same time,

19
00:01:12.051 --> 00:01:14.910
and creating what we call joins, right?

20
00:01:14.910 --> 00:01:17.560
Joins essentially, allows us to
link those tables together, and

21
00:01:17.560 --> 00:01:21.700
to ensure that we get the values
that we need as we actually make our

22
00:01:21.700 --> 00:01:25.230
queries a little bit more complex by
using the filtering that we can do.

23
00:01:25.230 --> 00:01:28.280
Instead of just returning what
we call a cartesian product.

24
00:01:28.280 --> 00:01:30.860
Now if anything that I said in those
last couple of sentences there,

25
00:01:30.860 --> 00:01:33.760
you're like whoa that was
a lot of information.

26
00:01:33.760 --> 00:01:36.190
Make sure you go back and watch part one,

27
00:01:36.190 --> 00:01:39.190
as we actually show you the examples of
what we're talking about right there.

28
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:41.350
So we're not gonna rehash all of that,

29
00:01:41.350 --> 00:01:44.558
but we do want to actually
continue to move forward here and

30
00:01:44.558 --> 00:01:48.691
take a look at some of the other things
that we have to actually worry about.

31
00:01:48.691 --> 00:01:52.945
One of the key features in terms of
dealing with the transact-SQL and

32
00:01:52.945 --> 00:01:57.709
your SQL server is that remember that your
SQL server has a ton of data normally

33
00:01:57.709 --> 00:02:00.448
that normally it's actually very active.

34
00:02:00.448 --> 00:02:03.592
There's always people pulling
information and a data from it.

35
00:02:03.592 --> 00:02:09.492
And so one of the best things that you and
I can actually end up doing is to make

36
00:02:09.492 --> 00:02:14.551
our particular queries as efficiently
written as they can be and

37
00:02:14.551 --> 00:02:18.110
to ensure that what we
actually do is we try and

38
00:02:18.110 --> 00:02:21.720
hit the engine as little as possible,
okay?

39
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:23.630
So, there's a couple of
things that are going on.

40
00:02:23.630 --> 00:02:25.180
Now you might say, well, Ronnie, why?

41
00:02:25.180 --> 00:02:28.950
Well, it is because if there are multiple
people writing queries against it,

42
00:02:28.950 --> 00:02:32.350
pulling information out,
it could be just two or three.

43
00:02:32.350 --> 00:02:34.110
But it could be hundreds,
it could be thousands,

44
00:02:34.110 --> 00:02:36.440
especially if you're
connected to a website.

45
00:02:36.440 --> 00:02:39.730
If you're actually doing all that stuff,
it could be millions of hits, for

46
00:02:39.730 --> 00:02:40.830
all you know.

47
00:02:40.830 --> 00:02:44.030
So one of the things that you're doing,
is actually making sure that you try to

48
00:02:44.030 --> 00:02:47.220
make your queries as
efficient as possible.

49
00:02:47.220 --> 00:02:51.100
Now, we've already shown that,
with multiple tables, when we need to pull

50
00:02:51.100 --> 00:02:55.230
the data up how to actually create
joins that will help us to do that.

51
00:02:55.230 --> 00:02:58.787
But the other thing that we
actually need to do sometimes,

52
00:02:58.787 --> 00:03:01.182
is to be able to create
data on the fly and

53
00:03:01.182 --> 00:03:06.068
use that data to be able to report that
to, what we call, another query, okay?

54
00:03:06.068 --> 00:03:08.874
And what we wanna do at that
particular point, right,

55
00:03:08.874 --> 00:03:12.969
is that we don't wanna actually create
another structure to hold data, okay?

56
00:03:12.969 --> 00:03:17.510
So let's think about something like
this that if every time we need to

57
00:03:17.510 --> 00:03:20.173
actually get a value from our database,

58
00:03:20.173 --> 00:03:24.112
and then I needed that value only for
another single query.

59
00:03:24.112 --> 00:03:27.103
Well what could end up happening
is that if the way that

60
00:03:27.103 --> 00:03:30.161
the database function is that
I will create an object,

61
00:03:30.161 --> 00:03:34.808
right, some type of software object
inside of my database so it can be used.

62
00:03:34.808 --> 00:03:37.070
Well, that begins to add up over time and

63
00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:39.560
actually adds up into space
that it's being stored on,

64
00:03:39.560 --> 00:03:43.920
which means more hits, more space,
more RAM that's actually being used.

65
00:03:43.920 --> 00:03:45.042
So sometimes you actually have to

66
00:03:45.042 --> 00:03:47.650
do things a little bit more efficiently,
okay?

67
00:03:47.650 --> 00:03:52.070
Now, there are actually permit structures
that are also made when you query your

68
00:03:52.070 --> 00:03:52.720
database.

69
00:03:52.720 --> 00:03:56.677
If you need stuff like that, and
you can actually build those things.

70
00:03:56.677 --> 00:04:01.768
Two of those things are what
we call temporary tables and

71
00:04:01.768 --> 00:04:04.703
also what we call views, okay?

72
00:04:04.703 --> 00:04:09.647
Now, let's take a look at my
machine here just for a moment, and

73
00:04:09.647 --> 00:04:13.676
we'll deal with the query
here in just a moment, but

74
00:04:13.676 --> 00:04:19.200
over here on the left hand side,
okay, inside of our Object Explorer.

75
00:04:19.200 --> 00:04:22.460
Oops, let me see if I can not do that,
how's that?

76
00:04:22.460 --> 00:04:26.550
Let me see if I can zoom in
just a little bit there, okay?

77
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:30.643
So, inside of the Object Explorer, notice
that I have my databases we're gonna be

78
00:04:30.643 --> 00:04:33.590
working with, this AdventureWorks2014.

79
00:04:33.590 --> 00:04:36.650
But up here at the top where
it says System Databases,

80
00:04:37.760 --> 00:04:42.140
if I expand that one out and also expand
out the tempdb, notice that there's

81
00:04:42.140 --> 00:04:47.920
actually something called
Temporary Tables and also Views, okay?

82
00:04:47.920 --> 00:04:51.100
So these are the objects that I was
actually mentioning that it gives us

83
00:04:51.100 --> 00:04:57.190
the ability to create these objects here
temporarily, and also Views that also

84
00:04:57.190 --> 00:05:01.200
allows us to create these objects that
we can also run queries against as well.

85
00:05:01.200 --> 00:05:05.567
But when we do stuff like this, usually
in Temporary Tables, its not only holding

86
00:05:05.567 --> 00:05:08.710
a structure temporarily for
you, so that you can do that.

87
00:05:08.710 --> 00:05:13.800
But then you actually have to run another
query to populate that table, okay?

88
00:05:13.800 --> 00:05:17.470
And then once you're done populating that
table, you have to run another query

89
00:05:17.470 --> 00:05:21.510
against that temporary table to
get the information you want out.

90
00:05:21.510 --> 00:05:24.780
And then, after that,
it also ends up cleaning up that table.

91
00:05:24.780 --> 00:05:28.920
In other words, when you actually do that
particular select statement against that

92
00:05:28.920 --> 00:05:30.070
temporary table,

93
00:05:30.070 --> 00:05:34.530
it then kinda weeds out all those other
fields you really didn't tend to use.

94
00:05:34.530 --> 00:05:35.515
>> That sounds simple, Ronnie.

95
00:05:35.515 --> 00:05:37.490
[LAUGH]
>> It sounds incredibly simple, okay?

96
00:05:37.490 --> 00:05:39.070
And it's a very powerful tool and

97
00:05:39.070 --> 00:05:41.445
something that we will end
up using a lot of times.

98
00:05:41.445 --> 00:05:42.444
>> I was being facetious.

99
00:05:42.444 --> 00:05:43.593
[LAUGH]
>> Sorry.

100
00:05:43.593 --> 00:05:46.838
[LAUGH]
>> Ronnies like this is easy.

101
00:05:46.838 --> 00:05:49.535
[LAUGH] Everybody does this.

102
00:05:49.535 --> 00:05:51.825
[LAUGH]
>> Well I thought so.

103
00:05:51.825 --> 00:05:56.252
[LAUGH] But
temporary tables are really helpful, okay?

104
00:05:56.252 --> 00:05:59.656
They're helpful when you do
need to run multiple times

105
00:05:59.656 --> 00:06:01.960
through that same set of data.

106
00:06:01.960 --> 00:06:05.490
You know it's gonna be constantly, you
know somebody else is gonna need to do it

107
00:06:05.490 --> 00:06:08.790
and something else is gonna need to
happen to it again and again and again.

108
00:06:08.790 --> 00:06:12.554
But sometimes when you actually create
something like that, it stays there and

109
00:06:12.554 --> 00:06:13.855
we forget about it, okay?

110
00:06:13.855 --> 00:06:17.935
And the idea of forgetting about it means
that more and more temporary tables that

111
00:06:17.935 --> 00:06:21.180
are created means more and
more of a workload on your SQL server.

112
00:06:21.180 --> 00:06:23.390
So you do need to go back in and
clean these things up.

113
00:06:23.390 --> 00:06:27.622
And the same thing with Views, creating
views is one of the neatest things

114
00:06:27.622 --> 00:06:30.489
cuz there's already bunches
of views in there for

115
00:06:30.489 --> 00:06:34.331
you to make database searching
a lot easier for you as well, okay?

116
00:06:34.331 --> 00:06:37.900
So a lot of times you actually do
have tons of views that are there.

117
00:06:37.900 --> 00:06:41.680
But then you can also create your own
that will also be stored here too.

118
00:06:41.680 --> 00:06:44.860
So all these actually
are storing the objects for us.

119
00:06:44.860 --> 00:06:47.660
But there are times though instead

120
00:06:47.660 --> 00:06:51.060
that what you need is
kinda the same experience.

121
00:06:51.060 --> 00:06:55.852
In terms of getting the data that you need
and returning a table of information,

122
00:06:55.852 --> 00:06:58.584
but only for
the query that you're running.

123
00:06:58.584 --> 00:07:03.001
Well, it seems a little bit of an overkill
then to actually create an actual table or

124
00:07:03.001 --> 00:07:05.160
a view, just for a single query, okay?

125
00:07:05.160 --> 00:07:10.158
If you really do need all that information
populated in the way that you need to,

126
00:07:10.158 --> 00:07:12.179
it seems like overkill to do it.

127
00:07:12.179 --> 00:07:16.219
But that's kinda some of the stuff that
normally has to happen if you actually

128
00:07:16.219 --> 00:07:19.961
are gonna be running queries that
are a little bit more complex, okay?

129
00:07:19.961 --> 00:07:23.365
So beyond the idea of just creating joins,
okay?

130
00:07:23.365 --> 00:07:27.435
Joins allow us to be able to pull
from multiple tables that exist in

131
00:07:27.435 --> 00:07:28.398
the database.

132
00:07:28.398 --> 00:07:31.451
But now what if you do need
information that you, or

133
00:07:31.451 --> 00:07:33.729
data that you've created on the fly?

134
00:07:33.729 --> 00:07:36.169
In other words,
something that was just generated and

135
00:07:36.169 --> 00:07:38.570
you still need to run
a query against that?

136
00:07:38.570 --> 00:07:42.440
Well you have those two options,
essentially creating a view or

137
00:07:42.440 --> 00:07:43.967
creating a temporary table, okay?

138
00:07:45.030 --> 00:07:49.760
But there's a third option that
we call a derived table, okay?

139
00:07:49.760 --> 00:07:54.085
A derived table is different in
the very fact that in one step-in-step,

140
00:07:54.085 --> 00:07:58.689
it creates a table like the temporary
table does, I know that sounds strange,

141
00:07:58.689 --> 00:08:00.523
but it does create that table.

142
00:08:00.523 --> 00:08:05.920
And it also populates the data
in that table at the same time.

143
00:08:05.920 --> 00:08:09.374
Remember that in temporary tables,
it actually creates the table structure

144
00:08:09.374 --> 00:08:11.509
first, then you have to
actually populate it.

145
00:08:11.509 --> 00:08:14.961
And then you have to actually run your
queries to get what you want out of it

146
00:08:14.961 --> 00:08:15.495
instead.

147
00:08:15.495 --> 00:08:19.758
Whereas in view so you essentially
actually create all that in one step.

148
00:08:19.758 --> 00:08:23.637
So let me show you the contrast of
what we're actually talking about that

149
00:08:23.637 --> 00:08:26.560
will help us to fill
this gap in a little bit.

150
00:08:26.560 --> 00:08:31.920
So here it is inside of my
SQL Management Studio here.

151
00:08:31.920 --> 00:08:34.180
And the first query that I want or

152
00:08:34.180 --> 00:08:39.190
ultimately what I want to do, is I want
a query to find out how I can categorize

153
00:08:39.190 --> 00:08:43.740
each of my customers into categories
based on the total sales themselves.

154
00:08:44.850 --> 00:08:46.630
So if I wanted to do that,

155
00:08:46.630 --> 00:08:51.210
how would I first approach it if
I were writing a SQL statement.

156
00:08:51.210 --> 00:08:55.490
So by myself if I were to think about that
one of the very first queries that I would

157
00:08:55.490 --> 00:09:00.840
end up doing is I would end up
creating a query that actually

158
00:09:00.840 --> 00:09:05.550
brings me the total sales by each customer
id and I would have it and type that out.

159
00:09:05.550 --> 00:09:10.466
So here it is, here is my SELECT statement
where I have the CustomerID, and

160
00:09:10.466 --> 00:09:15.270
I have the total of UnitPrice
times the OrderQty as TotalSales.

161
00:09:15.270 --> 00:09:19.300
And notice because though that data
actually comes from separate tables here,

162
00:09:19.300 --> 00:09:26.720
I did an inner joint on SalesOrderDetails
versus SalesOrderHeader.

163
00:09:26.720 --> 00:09:29.220
And then I went ahead and
grouped it and I ordered it as well.

164
00:09:30.440 --> 00:09:35.780
So that is the first information
that I want to go ahead and run.

165
00:09:35.780 --> 00:09:40.480

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain and implement 3 different types of Subqueries in SQL. They start off with the Scalar subquery, which is used to return a single value result. Next they look at the Multi-Valued subquery, which is used to return multiple results. Finally they test your logical aptitude with Correlated Subqueries which works together with the outer query.
episodes.title: Implement Subqueries

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue to examine the use of Subqueries in SQL. Here specifically they look at Pivoting and Un-Pivoting tables. Pivots will allow you to modify the returned data to turning row data into columns for easier viewing. Un-Pivot will be the reformatting of pivoted data back to normal.

Well, in that sense inside of Excel, we
