00:29:57.053 --> 00:30:01.124
The good thing is, well hopefully, I
believe we will, we'll have like all these

508
00:30:01.124 --> 00:30:04.487
queries will be available to you so
you can actually run these on your

509
00:30:04.487 --> 00:30:08.322
own versus your own 2014 database which
you can pull offline as well, and

510
00:30:08.322 --> 00:30:11.810
be able to actually set them up and
run them if you choose to.

511
00:30:11.810 --> 00:30:16.290
Ideally, hopefully what that actually does
is, it doesn't just let you run them but

512
00:30:16.290 --> 00:30:19.680
you can actually kind of parallel that and
run them with your own and

513
00:30:19.680 --> 00:30:23.820
make your own and that way you'll see
examples that are good and decent.

514
00:30:23.820 --> 00:30:24.720
I won't say good.

515
00:30:24.720 --> 00:30:29.857
Okay examples versus your own and go,
here's where I didn't actually see it.

516
00:30:29.857 --> 00:30:33.091
But, as you keep doing it the more
the logic's gonna make sense.

517
00:30:33.091 --> 00:30:34.620
And that's what has to happen.

518
00:30:34.620 --> 00:30:39.520
These things have to logically make sense
as you read them or you being able to pick

519
00:30:39.520 --> 00:30:43.820
out the right one, especially when you're
facing the exam, it's not gonna help you.

520
00:30:43.820 --> 00:30:47.330
Being able to understand when to
use them is just as important.

521
00:30:47.330 --> 00:30:48.920
And also in everything
else that we've done,

522
00:30:48.920 --> 00:30:53.080
we've also tried to show you when we get
error messages to show you those messages.

523
00:30:53.080 --> 00:30:56.080
Cuz one of the keys of course then,
is when you're working with SQL

524
00:30:56.080 --> 00:31:00.080
is to not let those error messages throw
you to the point where you just quit.

525
00:31:00.080 --> 00:31:02.040
I've done that a couple of times,

526
00:31:02.040 --> 00:31:04.290
where I'm like,
I'm just gonna do this tomorrow instead.

527
00:31:04.290 --> 00:31:06.020
But remember, time and

528
00:31:06.020 --> 00:31:10.830
your company is waiting on you to run
the proper queries that need to be done.

529
00:31:10.830 --> 00:31:13.150
Well, this is how you actually
start to create them.

530
00:31:13.150 --> 00:31:14.600
And the more complex your data is,

531
00:31:14.600 --> 00:31:17.450
the more you are going to need
these complex types of queries.

532
00:31:17.450 --> 00:31:20.610
Sub queries is one of the fundamental
things you have to get under your belt.

533
00:31:20.610 --> 00:31:22.260
>> Wise words from Mr. Ronnie Wong.

534
00:31:22.260 --> 00:31:23.950
Take heed and listen.

535
00:31:23.950 --> 00:31:26.120
That being said,
it is time for us to sign off.

536
00:31:26.120 --> 00:31:28.410
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

537
00:31:28.410 --> 00:31:29.249
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

538
00:31:29.249 --> 00:31:30.506
>> We'll see you next time.

539
00:31:30.506 --> 00:31:38.420
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish their look into Subqueries in SQL. They start off by exploring the use of the APPLY operator, which is a replacement for correlated subqueries and derived tables. Finally they demonstrate using a Common Table Expression(CTE).
episodes.title: Implement Subqueries Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.035 --> 00:00:17.177
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.177 --> 00:00:20.198
I am your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode

4
00:00:20.198 --> 00:00:24.639
we are continuing on with our querying
the Microsoft SQL 2014 Server.

5
00:00:24.639 --> 00:00:26.921
And joining us back in
the studio again today,

6
00:00:26.921 --> 00:00:29.738
just when you thought it was
safe to come back to ITProTV.

7
00:00:29.738 --> 00:00:31.673
>> [LAUGH]
>> The SQL master himself, Mr.

8
00:00:31.673 --> 00:00:32.433
Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:32.433 --> 00:00:34.310
Ronnie welcome back sir,
how's it going today?

10
00:00:34.310 --> 00:00:35.215
>> It is going great.

11
00:00:35.215 --> 00:00:38.850
As we continue to take a look at
more in the realm of sub-querying.

12
00:00:38.850 --> 00:00:40.340
I know you couldn't believe it,

13
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:43.880
that we could actually do any more,
but there's a lot in sub-querying.

14
00:00:43.880 --> 00:00:44.775
>> Can't get enough of it Ronnie.

15
00:00:44.775 --> 00:00:48.850
>> Yeah, most of us really can't until we
actually start seeing that I've done three

16
00:00:48.850 --> 00:00:49.980
episodes now on it.

17
00:00:49.980 --> 00:00:50.670
>> Now there's enough.

18
00:00:50.670 --> 00:00:53.520
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] now there's
plenty where we start seeing this.

19
00:00:53.520 --> 00:00:57.775
So now as we continue on, there's just a
couple of more different elements that we

20
00:00:57.775 --> 00:01:01.846
need to take a look at for sub-querying
that will help round out your skills for

21
00:01:01.846 --> 00:01:05.490
the exam, as well as some of
the elements that you'll see now.

22
00:01:05.490 --> 00:01:07.032
Every subquery that we've presented,

23
00:01:07.032 --> 00:01:12.290
I probably tend to emphasis
them as being equal things.

24
00:01:12.290 --> 00:01:16.510
A pivot and unpivot and the correlated and
the multi-valued as well as the scalar

25
00:01:16.510 --> 00:01:19.924
subqueries, all these that you've
seen in previous episodes,

26
00:01:19.924 --> 00:01:24.162
the emphasis has pretty much been where
it's like, this is something great.

27
00:01:24.162 --> 00:01:26.206
And the reality is a lot of times,

28
00:01:26.206 --> 00:01:30.586
you're probably gonna end up just
doing a few of them, but of course for

29
00:01:30.586 --> 00:01:35.990
the exam you don't know which one they're
really going to kind of poke your head on.

30
00:01:35.990 --> 00:01:39.621
It's hard to just go, guys,
don't worry about doing this one,

31
00:01:39.621 --> 00:01:43.270
worry more about doing this one,
I can't do that, right.

32
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:46.090
So the best thing that I can do is
actually just make sure I emphasize

33
00:01:46.090 --> 00:01:50.330
all of them, so that when it comes down
to it you at least have an understanding

34
00:01:50.330 --> 00:01:52.220
of what each of these
things actually does and

35
00:01:52.220 --> 00:01:55.550
you've seen a real example
of how they actually work.

36
00:01:55.550 --> 00:01:58.780
Even if you've never ran one before,
but you'll also get the opportunity and

37
00:01:58.780 --> 00:02:00.720
chance to actually be able
to do them on your own.

38
00:02:00.720 --> 00:02:03.350
So that's what we wanna make sure
that you actually get prepared for,

39
00:02:03.350 --> 00:02:07.350
because leaving you kinda high and dry on
any one of these would not be fair for

40
00:02:07.350 --> 00:02:11.560
you, nor would it be good since you're
getting ready to take that exam and

41
00:02:11.560 --> 00:02:14.370
pass that SQL Server exam as well.

42
00:02:14.370 --> 00:02:17.730
So, today we are moving a little
bit further in the realm

43
00:02:17.730 --> 00:02:20.500
of some of the different
sub-queries that we have available.

44
00:02:20.500 --> 00:02:26.630
And this particular subquery
is unusual in its purpose,

45
00:02:26.630 --> 00:02:30.260
when we start doing the idea of
subqueries here on this one.

46
00:02:30.260 --> 00:02:34.300
And that is because,
we are now moving into a one of these

47
00:02:34.300 --> 00:02:37.880
operators that we call the APPLY operator.

48
00:02:37.880 --> 00:02:42.596
Now when it comes down to what we're about
to do, you're gonna see something strange,

49
00:02:42.596 --> 00:02:45.780
which is not nothing I'd normally like to
show, but it's something that we have to

50
00:02:45.780 --> 00:02:48.480
be able to do to show you it
actually works the same way.

51
00:02:48.480 --> 00:02:53.170
So in anything that you saw, let's say for
example in a correlated query.

52
00:02:54.310 --> 00:02:57.830
I can actually go and
create a derived table.

53
00:02:57.830 --> 00:03:00.400
And if you're not sure what a derived
table is, make sure you go back to that

54
00:03:00.400 --> 00:03:04.610
episode and take a look at those
things in that derived table.

55
00:03:04.610 --> 00:03:08.890
I can take a derived table and
actually generate the same exact results.

56
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:11.760
And what we're actually starting to
see is that there's multiple and

57
00:03:11.760 --> 00:03:13.400
very many ways, right.

58
00:03:13.400 --> 00:03:18.240
So if I were to choose between
a correlated table versus a derived table,

59
00:03:18.240 --> 00:03:20.050
why would I choose one over the other?

60
00:03:20.050 --> 00:03:23.320
And we emphasize that in
that derived table episode.

61
00:03:23.320 --> 00:03:27.620
This time, we're actually going even
further to show you a third way,

62
00:03:27.620 --> 00:03:31.340
which is called using the APPLY operator,
as well.

63
00:03:31.340 --> 00:03:33.790
So everything that we're
about to show you now,

64
00:03:33.790 --> 00:03:37.510
also would generate
the same exact same query.

65
00:03:37.510 --> 00:03:41.440
But this time, there's actually
a different purpose to it, okay?

66
00:03:41.440 --> 00:03:45.790
Correlated queries, when we're actually
doing it is because a lot of times we're

67
00:03:45.790 --> 00:03:48.860
doing a sub-query, and it's not working
exactly the way that we need it to,

68
00:03:48.860 --> 00:03:52.200
because it's not reporting the data,
and getting some of that data back.

69
00:03:52.200 --> 00:03:54.930
And we talked about that in
the idea of a correlated query.

70
00:03:54.930 --> 00:03:59.460
That it can actually generate some
information on the outer query.

71
00:03:59.460 --> 00:04:00.780
Report that to the inner query, so

72
00:04:00.780 --> 00:04:05.840
that the inner query can report that
back out to the outer query again.

73
00:04:05.840 --> 00:04:09.200
So that way we can actually have something
like that, that actually does kinda bounce

74
00:04:09.200 --> 00:04:13.860
back and forth in terms of what it
actually generates for us to help us out.

75
00:04:13.860 --> 00:04:18.370
In the derived table, it's so that I don't
really need structures and functions

76
00:04:18.370 --> 00:04:22.470
that I continue to add to my database,
and essentially bloat the database.

77
00:04:22.470 --> 00:04:27.100
In a derived table, the existence of that
particular table that we end up creating

78
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:32.640
in RAM is only really good for returning
values to that single outer query and

79
00:04:32.640 --> 00:04:35.850
actually returning it one time as well.

80
00:04:35.850 --> 00:04:41.240
So when we actually want to run
the idea here of derived tables,

81
00:04:41.240 --> 00:04:44.292
it's great as long as it's actually
within that select statement and

82
00:04:44.292 --> 00:04:46.240
that we're only return it one time.

83
00:04:46.240 --> 00:04:47.910
And that's the only reason
why we would need it.

84
00:04:48.970 --> 00:04:54.320
Now what we are about to talk about here
today is what we call APPLY operators too.

85
00:04:54.320 --> 00:04:58.830
Now the good thing is we already have
some familiarity with the concept and

86
00:04:58.830 --> 00:05:00.816
how this is actually
going to work as well.

87
00:05:00.816 --> 00:05:05.210
And the reason that we do, we actually did
a whole episode, maybe even two episodes

88
00:05:05.210 --> 00:05:11.470
here, on creating select statements or
queries, my using join statements, too.

89
00:05:11.470 --> 00:05:14.700
Now, if you remember the idea of joins,
right,

90
00:05:14.700 --> 00:05:19.370
we take data from multiple tables
that exist in our database.

91
00:05:19.370 --> 00:05:22.100
We link them together, and
then we can query essentially,

92
00:05:22.100 --> 00:05:27.070
information from both to those tables, or
even multiple tables at the same time.

93
00:05:27.070 --> 00:05:30.020
And this is something that's actually
really great because it gets us out

94
00:05:30.020 --> 00:05:33.970
of that realm of only being able to create
a query and actually pull the information

95
00:05:33.970 --> 00:05:37.750
from one table, which would be fairly
limited in what we need to do.

96
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:42.680
So in this sense, then what APPLY
does is something a little bit

97
00:05:42.680 --> 00:05:45.360
kind of off the beaten
path a little bit more.

98
00:05:45.360 --> 00:05:49.771
In which, we instead can actually
do something like a join, but

99
00:05:49.771 --> 00:05:52.314
between select statements, okay.

100
00:05:52.314 --> 00:05:55.517
So, in other words,
when I actually run a subquery,

101
00:05:55.517 --> 00:06:00.362
I can actually create a join between those
two, instead of actually having to put

102
00:06:00.362 --> 00:06:05.515
things like inside a derived table, where
actually put it inside of the from clause.

103
00:06:05.515 --> 00:06:09.142
Or when I actually do
a regular scalar subquery or

104
00:06:09.142 --> 00:06:14.500
actually create the select statement
inside of the where clause.

105
00:06:14.500 --> 00:06:17.590
When we actually do an actual
real APPLY statement,

106
00:06:17.590 --> 00:06:20.940
we can actually create
two separate queries.

107
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:23.120
One does actually report
information back to the other and

108
00:06:23.120 --> 00:06:26.810
also it reports information back
to the original table as well.

109
00:06:26.810 --> 00:06:30.480
But they really do stand
independently by themselves, okay.

110
00:06:30.480 --> 00:06:34.623
Now you're saying, all right Ronnie,
that sound great, why?

111
00:06:34.623 --> 00:06:38.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> Why in the world would I do that?

112
00:06:38.160 --> 00:06:42.400
And it comes down to a matter of
efficiency is what it comes down to for

113
00:06:42.400 --> 00:06:43.570
databases.

114
00:06:43.570 --> 00:06:47.610
And that's kind of a key thing, and
Daniel, we had talked about this before.

115
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:52.320
Right now when I'm actually running this,
okay, my database isn't being hit

116
00:06:52.320 --> 00:06:57.040
by a web application o 10 or
12 other things that are going on.

117
00:06:57.040 --> 00:07:01.110
But in real life land, a database is hit.

118
00:07:01.110 --> 00:07:02.372
What do you think, lots?

119
00:07:02.372 --> 00:07:04.021
>> Lots is not the term.

120
00:07:04.021 --> 00:07:07.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> Lots and lots and lots and lots.

121
00:07:07.660 --> 00:07:11.780
Our database input output, the demand for

122
00:07:11.780 --> 00:07:15.446
the drive is extremely high, right.

123
00:07:15.446 --> 00:07:20.100
This is why we look for
super fast disks, we separate it out so

124
00:07:20.100 --> 00:07:23.767
that only database traffic
is going into this.

125
00:07:23.767 --> 00:07:28.087
There's a lot that we take into account
to try to make sure that our databases

126
00:07:28.087 --> 00:07:30.463
are running as efficiently as possible.

127
00:07:30.463 --> 00:07:34.923
Because of the amount of requests
that are going toward them.

128
00:07:34.923 --> 00:07:37.590
So Ronnie I think I see where
you're going with this.

129
00:07:37.590 --> 00:07:42.220
We're trying to create queries,
that run a little more efficiency.

130
00:07:42.220 --> 00:07:45.500
We always wanna make sure that everything
we do, when in regards to our database,

131
00:07:45.500 --> 00:07:46.810
is as efficient as possible.

132
00:07:46.810 --> 00:07:50.980
And you think, well it only runs a little
bit more efficient if I do it this way.

133
00:07:50.980 --> 00:07:52.270
And yeah, you're right.

134
00:07:52.270 --> 00:07:56.450
But if you aggregate that,
if all of a sudden you take one query and

135
00:07:56.450 --> 00:08:00.250
you multiply it by 1000,
now all that little bit adds up

136
00:08:00.250 --> 00:08:05.203
to a lot less traffic Cuz if it was there,
you would definitely see a bog down.

137
00:08:05.203 --> 00:08:09.228
>> And that's where we really
wanna focus in on the reason for

138
00:08:09.228 --> 00:08:14.380
doing something like what we call
the apply type of query, as well.

139
00:08:14.380 --> 00:08:16.530
So let's go in and
show you kind of the basics here, and

140
00:08:16.530 --> 00:08:18.850
then lead up to what's going to happen.

141
00:08:18.850 --> 00:08:22.950
I hope, at least, in my mind,
that it actually did work out,

142
00:08:22.950 --> 00:08:24.950
of course people will understand
it the exact same way I will,

143
00:08:24.950 --> 00:08:28.190
I can't really guarantee that but
at least we'll show you.

144
00:08:28.190 --> 00:08:31.440
So let's take for
example a simple correlated query.

145
00:08:31.440 --> 00:08:33.730
Now remember that in this
correlated query here,

146
00:08:33.730 --> 00:08:37.030
I have this outer select, oop, well,
that's gonna actually be great.

147
00:08:37.030 --> 00:08:41.160
This outer select statement right
here along with the from as well,

148
00:08:41.160 --> 00:08:44.260
and so I have that ability to run that.

149
00:08:44.260 --> 00:08:45.930
But then we were doing subqueries right?

150
00:08:45.930 --> 00:08:49.260
We also have this,
inner select statement too.

151
00:08:49.260 --> 00:08:50.110
Now, if I try and

152
00:08:50.110 --> 00:08:53.930
run that, when we did a scalar sub query,
it ran perfectly fine, right?

153
00:08:53.930 --> 00:08:57.810
But now notice it says look,
I can't find the information for this and

154
00:08:57.810 --> 00:09:00.370
the reason why I can't is that
it's referring to these tables and

155
00:09:00.370 --> 00:09:04.910
it has no real reference for,
let's say this SOH here,

156
00:09:04.910 --> 00:09:09.090
the sales order header table,
because I actually only ran that query.

157
00:09:09.090 --> 00:09:11.700
I didn't define it in a join or any place.

158
00:09:11.700 --> 00:09:13.330
So where does it have to
retrieve that information?

159
00:09:13.330 --> 00:09:16.210
It has to go to the outer table
to retrieve that information.

160
00:09:16.210 --> 00:09:20.930
So before this particular query can run,
well, it actually has to say,

161
00:09:20.930 --> 00:09:24.270
hey, I need information from
this outer query right here,

162
00:09:24.270 --> 00:09:27.050
which is actually
the information right here.

163
00:09:27.050 --> 00:09:30.590
So that I can actually generate and
run this and

164
00:09:30.590 --> 00:09:35.440
if I run this it means I can actually
return to you the max unit price, okay?

165
00:09:35.440 --> 00:09:38.060
So notice that that's where we

166
00:09:38.060 --> 00:09:40.946
kind of had taken a look at
our correlated query right?

167
00:09:40.946 --> 00:09:45.380
The inside has to actually called upon the
outer query to return a bit of information

168
00:09:45.380 --> 00:09:49.150
before it can actually run the
information, the entire select statement.

169
00:09:49.150 --> 00:09:52.750
To return the value that the outer
query is actually asking for.

170
00:09:52.750 --> 00:09:56.761
So it is like I described in the other
episode, it is enigma wrapped

171
00:09:56.761 --> 00:10:00.716
in a conundrum wrapped in a subquery
wrapped in a burrito, okay.

172
00:10:00.716 --> 00:10:01.932
[LAUGH] So that's what we have.

173
00:10:01.932 --> 00:10:03.395
>> A number five at Taco Bell.

174
00:10:03.395 --> 00:10:06.420
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and the results that might follow

175
00:10:06.420 --> 00:10:08.324
after that [CROSSTALK]
>> That's right, so

176
00:10:08.324 --> 00:10:11.120
sometimes you can have something
like that that comes on.

177
00:10:11.120 --> 00:10:12.600
But notice this, right?

178
00:10:12.600 --> 00:10:14.950
Well just think about that one query,
right?

179
00:10:14.950 --> 00:10:18.010
Just in the dizzying
logic that I showed you.

180
00:10:18.010 --> 00:10:21.166
And Daniel is like [SOUND]
just in that logic.

181
00:10:21.166 --> 00:10:25.820
Well imagine running that thing
against a database server.

182
00:10:25.820 --> 00:10:29.250
That's what hit the way that
Daniel was describing it, right?

183
00:10:29.250 --> 00:10:34.010
The very fact that it's 10,000 per hour
of different queries that are going on or

184
00:10:34.010 --> 00:10:35.070
even more.

185
00:10:35.070 --> 00:10:39.980
Well, think about the generation that
this one thing could actually have and

186
00:10:39.980 --> 00:10:44.520
the amount of processing units

that really, like I said,

413
00:23:40.892 --> 00:23:42.194
I want to show an example.

414
00:23:42.194 --> 00:23:44.876
But, the key here is actually
being able to identify.

415
00:23:44.876 --> 00:23:48.231
And that's what we are really focusing
in on, is the identification and

416
00:23:48.231 --> 00:23:50.490
of course of why you would
actually choose that.

417
00:23:50.490 --> 00:23:54.449
So if you're actually iterating through
your data with a query, then that's what

418
00:23:54.449 --> 00:23:58.314
you're actually trying to do is try to
show those iterations is the other thing.

419
00:23:58.314 --> 00:24:00.450
So, that is a key difference.

420
00:24:00.450 --> 00:24:03.685
Compared to derived query This one you
can actually run over and over again.

421
00:24:03.685 --> 00:24:07.611
It's designed for that idea of iteration,
whereas drive, designed for

422
00:24:07.611 --> 00:24:10.850
a one time run,
is what we're normally doing here, okay?

423
00:24:10.850 --> 00:24:16.830
So, let's take a look at my screen as
we continue to move forward here, okay?

424
00:24:16.830 --> 00:24:21.630
So first thing, I'm gonna do is make sure
I'm connected to the right database and

425
00:24:21.630 --> 00:24:23.740
then we'll take a look.

426
00:24:23.740 --> 00:24:27.310
All right, when it comes down to it, this
is kinda one of the strange things, okay.

427
00:24:27.310 --> 00:24:34.530
Is that even though its called CTE, you
normally define it at the very beginning,

00:24:34.530 --> 00:24:37.910
and that's what you have to do, you have
to define what we call the CTE expression.

429
00:24:37.910 --> 00:24:40.500
And then you can also have a column list.

430
00:24:40.500 --> 00:24:44.360
So I have a column list, and
this particular column list,

431
00:24:44.360 --> 00:24:47.730
people have left it off, and
it's worked perfectly fine.

432
00:24:47.730 --> 00:24:49.790
I recommend that you
actually create it yourself.

433
00:24:49.790 --> 00:24:54.240
So remember, you're trying to create,
essentially, a drive table, but

434
00:24:54.240 --> 00:24:57.330
without it actually being called
a drive table, so here it is.

435
00:24:57.330 --> 00:25:02.740
I'm actually going to name my
common table expression and

436
00:25:02.740 --> 00:25:06.110
you have to start off with the word with.

437
00:25:06.110 --> 00:25:10.817
With, you give it a name, and
then you also essential create a column

438
00:25:10.817 --> 00:25:15.380
list of the columns that you actually
are gonna have in this table.

439
00:25:15.380 --> 00:25:16.100
Okay?

440
00:25:16.100 --> 00:25:20.200
Now, how do you actually get
those columns in that new table.

441
00:25:20.200 --> 00:25:24.700
Well, you now define it by
using a select statement, okay?

442
00:25:24.700 --> 00:25:28.060
So we're actually going to
define that CTE query, and

443
00:25:28.060 --> 00:25:33.450
you can take a look right here what
it's actually being defined as, okay?

444
00:25:33.450 --> 00:25:35.720
So we're gonna take a look
at the SalesPersonID,

445
00:25:35.720 --> 00:25:38.690
their OrderID, and the YEAR, okay?

446
00:25:38.690 --> 00:25:40.190
And we're gonna actually say, so

447
00:25:40.190 --> 00:25:43.760
essentially we're taking a look
at the sales by each year.

448
00:25:43.760 --> 00:25:48.740
As long as there's actually a sales ID.

449
00:25:48.740 --> 00:25:51.640
So, we don't want there to actually
be sales that don't have a sales

450
00:25:51.640 --> 00:25:53.210
ID attached to it.

451
00:25:53.210 --> 00:25:53.710
Okay?

452
00:25:54.840 --> 00:25:57.600
Then, we have to define the outer query.

453
00:25:57.600 --> 00:25:59.140
Now, notice,
because we're talking about inner and

454
00:25:59.140 --> 00:26:03.280
outer query, It is a sub-form
of a sub-query here, okay.

455
00:26:03.280 --> 00:26:06.970
So at this point we also
define the outer query.

456
00:26:06.970 --> 00:26:09.720
And notice that that one's listed third.

457
00:26:09.720 --> 00:26:12.550
So we're actually going
to say SalesPersonID.

458
00:26:12.550 --> 00:26:17.650
Count up all the sales order IDs
as total sales and the sales year.

459
00:26:17.650 --> 00:26:21.960
But now this is where we call upon
that little table that we just created

460
00:26:21.960 --> 00:26:23.130
right here.

461
00:26:23.130 --> 00:26:24.510
So now we defined it.

462
00:26:24.510 --> 00:26:27.040
We gave it a name and we defined it, and

463
00:26:27.040 --> 00:26:31.440
then in the outer query we use
it in the from clause here.

464
00:26:31.440 --> 00:26:32.400
So we're actually telling it,

465
00:26:32.400 --> 00:26:35.490
don't going through the database
to find the information.

466
00:26:35.490 --> 00:26:38.937
Go into my common table
expression to find that.

467
00:26:38.937 --> 00:26:41.510
Now the underscore CTE,
do you have to do that?

468
00:26:41.510 --> 00:26:42.030
No.

469
00:26:42.030 --> 00:26:43.770
You can name it whatever you want to.

470
00:26:43.770 --> 00:26:47.880
It just makes it easy to identify when
you do actually create something like

471
00:26:47.880 --> 00:26:49.530
a CTE for yourself.

472
00:26:49.530 --> 00:26:54.000
Then you can do the standard regular
groups bys and order bys as well.

473
00:26:54.000 --> 00:26:58.590
Because I have an aggregate up
here in the select statement,

474
00:26:58.590 --> 00:27:02.690
it means I also have to aggregate
together the salesperson ID

475
00:27:02.690 --> 00:27:08.120
as well as the SalesYear and that's why
both of those are also in the group by.

476
00:27:08.120 --> 00:27:11.880
And if I'm actually to group
by that I'm also going to say

477
00:27:11.880 --> 00:27:16.850
hey also give me an order by as far
the sorting order do the SalesPersonID and

478
00:27:16.850 --> 00:27:19.060
then the SalesYear second.

479
00:27:19.060 --> 00:27:19.850
Now if I try and

480
00:27:19.850 --> 00:27:23.180
run each one of those statements
separately it's not going to run.

481
00:27:23.180 --> 00:27:27.397
So here I can simply execute the whole,
I'm lying to you.

482
00:27:27.397 --> 00:27:28.562
>> Don't lie to us-
>> I am,

483
00:27:28.562 --> 00:27:29.997
I selected-
>> Don't break the-

484
00:27:29.997 --> 00:27:30.612
>> That's what happened.

485
00:27:30.612 --> 00:27:32.238
>> Trust relationship we have-
>> There we go.

486
00:27:32.238 --> 00:27:33.120
>> With your falsehoods.

487
00:27:33.120 --> 00:27:34.326
>> It wasn't, I mean that's-
>> [LAUGH]

488
00:27:34.326 --> 00:27:35.244
>> Exactly what happened.

489
00:27:35.244 --> 00:27:38.925
I apparently selected something
while I was doing that and so

490
00:27:38.925 --> 00:27:40.738
I selected a little bit here.

491
00:27:40.738 --> 00:27:44.439
So now you can see the results and
there's about 58 rows here.

492
00:27:45.900 --> 00:27:50.680
And so it returns to me,
this particular tabular value.

493
00:27:50.680 --> 00:27:53.740
And this is exactly what was in the CTE.

494
00:27:53.740 --> 00:27:59.720
So now I can see the sales person
274 in 2011, he had 4 total sales,

495
00:27:59.720 --> 00:28:03.180
but in 2012, he had 22 and 2013,

496
00:28:03.180 --> 00:28:08.710
he had 14 and then 2014,
he had eight sales here.

497
00:28:08.710 --> 00:28:09.260
Okay.

498
00:28:09.260 --> 00:28:14.030
Which if you add up all of those,
he did nothing compared to 275,

499
00:28:14.030 --> 00:28:17.360
who did 65 sales in 2011.

500
00:28:17.360 --> 00:28:21.496
So you can see where this
can be useful for you but

501
00:28:21.496 --> 00:28:27.609
most of the time we're probably not
gonna get that far in all reality.

502
00:28:27.609 --> 00:28:29.072
On the exam, yes.

503
00:28:29.072 --> 00:28:32.450
Okay, it's a possibility that you
would choose from all these tools.

504
00:28:32.450 --> 00:28:35.190
It's sort of like being
a chef in a kitchen, right?

505
00:28:35.190 --> 00:28:38.620
And you got 16 different

00:28:38.620 --> 00:28:42.580
all of them are razor sharp because you
handed them to Daniel to sharpen but

00:28:42.580 --> 00:28:43.830
what happens when you're a chef?

00:28:43.830 --> 00:28:45.020
You tend to stick with what?

509
00:28:45.020 --> 00:28:46.270
You tend to go for your favorite.

510
00:28:46.270 --> 00:28:47.550
>> The one you like, yeah.

511
00:28:47.550 --> 00:28:50.090
And in reality for
subqueries, it's what we do.

00:28:50.090 --> 00:28:52.740
We tend to go here's the one

513
00:28:52.740 --> 00:28:56.620
here's the one that I stick with but on
the exam you do need to know about CT's.

00:28:56.620 --> 00:28:58.460
You do need to know about derived tables.

515
00:28:58.460 --> 00:29:00.470
You do need to know about
those correlated subqueries,

516
00:29:00.470 --> 00:29:04.045
multi valued scalar subqueries,
PIVOTs and UNPIVOTs.

517
00:29:04.045 --> 00:29:07.933
[INAUDIBLE] I was trying to
think of which one I forgot.

518
00:29:07.933 --> 00:29:11.000
[INAUDIBLE] We have all

But more than likely,
like I said, in real life land,

00:29:14.100 --> 00:29:18.680
you're gonna stick with your particular

00:29:18.680 --> 00:29:20.575
and you're gonna slice and dice that data.

522
00:29:20.575 --> 00:29:22.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well what Ronnie's trying to tell

you is, don't pigeonhole yourself.

00:29:24.230 --> 00:29:25.500
Learn all these things.

00:29:25.500 --> 00:29:29.140
And obviously, you're gonna have
your favorites, your go-tos.

00:29:29.140 --> 00:29:32.500
But you need to be familiar with all
the others as well cuz, well hey,

00:29:32.500 --> 00:29:36.030
you want to pass an exam and
you never know when it'll be handy for

Ronnie, is there anything else we

but we do have a lot more to cover in our

00:29:48.430 --> 00:29:51.290
And as you can see, some neat things
that maybe most of us haven't actually

00:29:54.490 --> 00:29:57.590
depth things as well, but

But remember that for us in practicing the

So there's no other way for me to say it.

I can't tell you that this subquery's

overall, though, you've just gotta

they mean all of these.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the concept and different implementations of aggregate queries. They start by taking a look at GROUPING SETS which will define the groups. Next they explore the CUBE statement which creates every possible group. Finally, they explain the ROLLUP statement which will create a group with a hierarchy.
episodes.title: Implement Aggregate Queries

And in today's episode,

we are moving on with our querying

Joining us back in the studio

Ronnie welcome back sir.

How's it going?

00:00:32.480 --> 00:00:36.300
>> It is going well as we continue

00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:38.990

12

And now we're actually moving beyond
the realm of some of the things that we've

It feels like we've been stuck in it for

15
00:00:44.616 --> 00:00:46.730
>> [LAUGH]

the idea of moving beyond subqueries,
moving beyond the idea of

Now when we start thinking about that,

a lot of times people aren't

But the idea of aggregation is

A lot of times that also involves the idea

So whenever you actually start to

Let's take for an example just a simple

00:01:19.080 --> 00:01:22.870
we have companies and

28

And there can then be a single customer

And what I might want to do

00:01:33.751 --> 00:01:38.230
So what I'm doing something like that

And I need to be able to take the

33
00:01:41.430 --> 00:01:44.650

34
00:01:44.650 --> 00:01:49.040
Inside of my database, and then be able to

36
00:01:54.960 --> 00:01:57.180
Either a year to date, or all the way

37
00:01:57.180 --> 00:02:01.550
whatever it might be, I need to be

38
00:02:01.550 --> 00:02:06.290
Now when we start dealing with the idea of
grouping then, and starting to do that,

there's a couple of different things

00:02:09.600 --> 00:02:10.470

00:02:10.470 --> 00:02:15.020
Very simply we can use what we call
aggregation functions to help us right at

00:02:15.020 --> 00:02:15.970
the beginning.

00:02:15.970 --> 00:02:19.560
But then we need to take a look at more

So, let's go ahead and start that way.

00:02:23.090 --> 00:02:25.050
We're gonna start taking
a look at idea of grouping and

then we're gonna move into
something called grouping sets too.

48
00:02:28.770 --> 00:02:32.710
So here it is on my
particular screen here.

49
00:02:32.710 --> 00:02:36.835
I have of course a SQL query

at the simplest and
most basic level, okay?

51

When we start talking about the idea of

52
00:02:44.463 --> 00:02:48.700
We can do it right here in
the select clause itself.

53
00:02:48.700 --> 00:02:53.400
And notice that what I'm doing is I'm
taking the sales year-to-date from this

00:02:53.400 --> 00:02:56.510
particular table which
is a sales territory and

00:02:56.510 --> 00:03:01.760

Now I should probably ask you to

57
00:03:04.760 --> 00:03:08.450
So let me kind of zoom, oop look at that,

00:03:08.450 --> 00:03:10.090
So now, let me go ahead and

00:03:10.090 --> 00:03:12.880

00:03:16.160 --> 00:03:18.630
So we'll say average sales.

62
00:03:18.630 --> 00:03:22.980
And so if I wanna go ahead and

00:03:22.980 --> 00:03:24.590

And now notice that it's taken everyone

A single summary,

00:03:36.550 --> 00:03:39.160
So I have a single value here

00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:41.060

00:03:41.060 --> 00:03:42.020
And so that's what we're doing.

00:03:42.020 --> 00:03:44.200
We're aggregating all of

Now even though that might help me

That all my sales We'll

78

But normally that's a little bit

So if we think about it, that figure

So we're actually wanting to go ahead and

I wanna see what each territory

Well you can see that I also

Sum and then I've also included an alias.

00:04:37.690 --> 00:04:39.830
Now hopefully you're starting to see this.

88
00:04:39.830 --> 00:04:42.440
If you've gone through the series

00:04:42.440 --> 00:04:45.890
the way that these are kind of numbered,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their discussion on aggregate queries, picking up by looking at the use of the RANK() function, which assigns a value to data for sorting purposes. They also show you how to add row numbers and even grouping data by percentile using the NTILE() function.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish their look at aggregate queries by discussing Spatial Aggregates. Spatial aggregates allow you to visualize data by using a map(Geographical) or a shape(Geometrical). They walk you through the 4 Spatial Aggregate types including: Union, Envelope, Collection, and Convex.

00:16:20.910 --> 00:16:23.740
But I didn't want to
actually divide it up.

303
00:16:23.740 --> 00:16:26.690
I didn't even want the shape
of Florida to show up.

304
00:16:26.690 --> 00:16:29.980
I just wanted to be able
to represent it as a whole.

305
00:16:29.980 --> 00:16:32.440
And the idea of an envelope is this,
right,

306
00:16:32.440 --> 00:16:34.350
is that it actually does represent it.

307
00:16:34.350 --> 00:16:37.470
Even though it's actually just a square,
it represents, but

308
00:16:37.470 --> 00:16:39.910
it envelopes the entire state here.

309
00:16:39.910 --> 00:16:45.050
Now, we can of course do this and that
is what they call a Polygonal Envelope.

310
00:16:46.090 --> 00:16:46.948
Go figure, okay?

311
00:16:46.948 --> 00:16:49.690
So that's because I've
got multiple sides here.

312
00:16:49.690 --> 00:16:52.720
Polygonal, I know, neat term, right?

313
00:16:52.720 --> 00:16:57.631
Or we can actually use a circle to
essentially do the same thing, okay?

314
00:16:57.631 --> 00:17:02.419
Now, this one of course has a fancier
name, it's called a Curved Polygonal.

315
00:17:02.419 --> 00:17:04.730
Even though there's no sides to a circle.

316
00:17:04.730 --> 00:17:06.160
But there you go.

317
00:17:06.160 --> 00:17:10.530
So you do have where you can actually
use those types to help us out.

318
00:17:10.530 --> 00:17:14.300
And you may do something like that
if you want just to represent that.

319
00:17:14.300 --> 00:17:17.500
Hey, Florida has customers, okay?

320
00:17:17.500 --> 00:17:18.530
In whatever state you want.

321
00:17:18.530 --> 00:17:23.320
But you're not really trying to get so
interested in the geography of it itself.

322
00:17:23.320 --> 00:17:27.300
But we can use envelope types
like that to help us out.

323
00:17:27.300 --> 00:17:30.870
If that's what we wanna represent
especially among a group of

324
00:17:30.870 --> 00:17:34.718
different objects and we just didn't
wanna do an entire map that we wanted to.

325
00:17:34.718 --> 00:17:40.409
Of course, there's also what we
call Collection Aggregates instead.

326
00:17:40.409 --> 00:17:45.450
Sometimes, let's say that the original
map you had is fairly fancy.

327
00:17:45.450 --> 00:17:48.590
Okay so, you actually had
that inside your database.

328
00:17:48.590 --> 00:17:52.310
So here I chose Australia as an example
and the reason why I did is it's simpler

329
00:17:52.310 --> 00:17:54.370
and I like the colors that
I actually put out here.

330
00:17:54.370 --> 00:17:57.080
So, you can actually choose like here and

331
00:17:57.080 --> 00:18:02.420
notice a Collection Aggregation is not
really getting rid of the sections.

332
00:18:02.420 --> 00:18:06.960
But it's just simply saying look, we want
this to look, as a collective whole, so

333
00:18:06.960 --> 00:18:09.612
instead of dividing it up with
the individual colors here,

334
00:18:09.612 --> 00:18:14.040
we're gonna still report
the same boundaries, but

335
00:18:14.040 --> 00:18:19.570
now we're actually making what, a single
collection instead, as an aggregation.

336
00:18:19.570 --> 00:18:23.310
And so here we just change the actual
aggregate name, chose country,

337
00:18:23.310 --> 00:18:27.010
and this time I chose the abbreviation
here for Australia instead.

338
00:18:27.010 --> 00:18:31.230
So these collection aggregates can also
help us to display it in that way, and

339
00:18:31.230 --> 00:18:35.990
then I can put that spacial information
that we had before, overlay it, and put it

340
00:18:35.990 --> 00:18:39.470
right there on the map, and that way
you can see the little individual dots.

341
00:18:39.470 --> 00:18:43.390
Find all those Taco Bells in Australia for
our friend Daniel over here, and

342
00:18:43.390 --> 00:18:44.606
he'd be happy and ready to go.

343
00:18:44.606 --> 00:18:47.730
[LAUGH]
>> I get $5 every time I mention

344
00:18:47.730 --> 00:18:49.670
Taco Bell, Taco Bell, Taco Bell.

345
00:18:49.670 --> 00:18:50.580
Just kidding.

346
00:18:50.580 --> 00:18:51.680
>> Do they know that?

347
00:18:51.680 --> 00:18:55.830
>> I didn't say I got $5 bucks from them.

348
00:18:55.830 --> 00:18:56.770
>> Well, that's true.

349
00:18:56.770 --> 00:19:00.863
All right, now our last one's
a little bit unusual, at least for

350
00:19:00.863 --> 00:19:03.550
me it's a little bit more unusual, okay?

351
00:19:03.550 --> 00:19:07.271
But there was, I was trying to think
about how do I show this cuz you know,

352
00:19:07.271 --> 00:19:08.730
this is done statically.

353
00:19:08.730 --> 00:19:12.890
Dynamically it would be one thing, like
yeah I just feed this in and it works, but

354
00:19:12.890 --> 00:19:16.170
statically trying to show it is
a little bit more unusual, okay?

355
00:19:16.170 --> 00:19:20.560
Last one is what they call
a convex hull aggregate.

356
00:19:20.560 --> 00:19:22.940
I'll probably never
have to say that again.

357
00:19:22.940 --> 00:19:24.130
But no, more than likely I will.

358
00:19:24.130 --> 00:19:28.030
But just kinda realize that this
is something else here, okay?

359
00:19:28.030 --> 00:19:29.900
So what they're saying
with the ConvexHull,

360
00:19:29.900 --> 00:19:32.780
notice again the only thing I
really changed is right here.

361
00:19:32.780 --> 00:19:33.920
ConvexHullAggregate.

362
00:19:33.920 --> 00:19:36.330
Remember you have to include
the data type in here.

363
00:19:36.330 --> 00:19:37.280
Change the region.

364
00:19:37.280 --> 00:19:39.880
And then in Australia as well.

365
00:19:39.880 --> 00:19:41.340
Let's see, that should be country.

366
00:19:41.340 --> 00:19:41.930
I'm sorry.

367
00:19:41.930 --> 00:19:43.810
See I forgot to change one thing here.

368
00:19:43.810 --> 00:19:44.590
Let me verify.

369
00:19:44.590 --> 00:19:47.020
Change that to country this time.

370
00:19:47.020 --> 00:19:49.410
There we go,
that'll make a little bit more sense.

371
00:19:49.410 --> 00:19:54.980
To take the entire country, and instead of
actually showing you a map of the country,

372
00:19:54.980 --> 00:19:59.590
I want it to be the same thing,
the idea of some type of polygon.

373
00:19:59.590 --> 00:20:04.770
But I want it as much as possible,
to hug the shape, Okay?

374
00:20:04.770 --> 00:20:07.100
So wherever I can I'm trying
to actually hug the shape.

375
00:20:07.100 --> 00:20:08.760
I don't know if you can
actually see that yellow.

376
00:20:08.760 --> 00:20:10.510
Can you see that yellow?

377
00:20:10.510 --> 00:20:11.200
I'm hoping you can.

378
00:20:11.200 --> 00:20:14.390
I probably should have made that black or
so, but yeah.

379
00:20:14.390 --> 00:20:16.920
But then, now that we have that shape,

380
00:20:16.920 --> 00:20:19.880
I'm gonna move this out of the way
to try to make my point, right?

381
00:20:19.880 --> 00:20:23.170
Well, then we can represent
that by what we see over

382
00:20:23.170 --> 00:20:27.430
here on the right hand side instead
which is just that particular shape.

383
00:20:27.430 --> 00:20:32.200
So if you did have countries that you
wanted, or even counties that you want,

384
00:20:32.200 --> 00:20:35.300
but you didn't want to get so
detailed into, that's not the shape,

385
00:20:35.300 --> 00:20:37.290
you just wanted to represent it this way.

386
00:20:37.290 --> 00:20:41.570
Well, you can instead actually have a
shape instead of just a square or a circle

387
00:20:41.570 --> 00:20:47.650
that will allow you to kind of almost
feel like it's actually the real thing,

388
00:20:47.650 --> 00:20:51.880
but you wanted to be a little bit more
abstract with your particular creation,

389
00:20:51.880 --> 00:20:55.330
and represent that as being
Australia at the same time too.

390
00:20:55.330 --> 00:20:56.961
>> Get all Salvador Dali on it.

391
00:20:56.961 --> 00:20:59.779
[LAUGH]
>> I guess you could if you wanted too.

392
00:20:59.779 --> 00:21:04.580
So this is where you might actually do
some type of very basic layout plan.

393
00:21:04.580 --> 00:21:05.650
Let's say like a map, right?

394
00:21:05.650 --> 00:21:07.640
If you wanted to draw
a very simple map for

395
00:21:07.640 --> 00:21:12.290
your customers, you might put your store
over here and just have a shape, and

396
00:21:12.290 --> 00:21:15.130
then say, here's how you get
to it from the highway, and

397
00:21:15.130 --> 00:21:19.360
have a different shape that represents
that, or whatever it might be.

398
00:21:19.360 --> 00:21:24.900
So we can actually use this to kind of
help if you wanted to do more abstraction

399
00:21:24.900 --> 00:21:29.680
wise types of things, to help understand
that idea of that spatial relationship.

400
00:21:29.680 --> 00:21:32.200
So remember the requirements here though,
okay?

401
00:21:32.200 --> 00:21:34.830
First and foremost,
you have to have data, okay?

402
00:21:34.830 --> 00:21:41.287
That actually has, as its data type,
either geometry, okay, or geography, okay?

403
00:21:41.287 --> 00:21:43.740
So that is pretty much the key.

404
00:21:43.740 --> 00:21:47.640
So in other words, if it can actually do
like the coordinate values and stuff, and

405
00:21:47.640 --> 00:21:51.400
show you a linear path from here to there,
then that can actually do that idea and

406
00:21:51.400 --> 00:21:54.060
that's what that geometry is about, okay?

407
00:21:54.060 --> 00:21:59.110
Or you can do the geography itself, again
it can take even things like the GPS data,

408
00:21:59.110 --> 00:22:02.560
go to map that stuff out for
it, pull the map data in and

409
00:22:02.560 --> 00:22:05.470
now you can actually display it
in one of those different ways.

410
00:22:05.470 --> 00:22:09.040
Whether it's the Union Aggregate that you
end up using, the Envelope Aggregate,

411
00:22:09.040 --> 00:22:12.860
the Collection, or
even if the ConvexHullAggregate,

412
00:22:12.860 --> 00:22:17.340
it normally can help you display data
that you're not used to displaying

413
00:22:17.340 --> 00:22:21.900
in a way that will really be helpful for
you or your customers in a different way.

414
00:22:21.900 --> 00:22:25.780
So, hopefully that's a good overview for
us, and it's another way to show more

415
00:22:25.780 --> 00:22:29.800
aggregation that can be done inside
using our select statements.

416
00:22:29.800 --> 00:22:33.590
>> Yeah, it's very cool stuff,
this whole Spacial Aggregation business.

417
00:22:33.590 --> 00:22:37.837
I think spatially anyway so it was really
good for me to see how this can work.

418
00:22:37.837 --> 00:22:39.301
Just random data on a table,

419
00:22:39.301 --> 00:22:43.535
a lot of times it just ends up not really
giving the punch that you're looking for.

420
00:22:43.535 --> 00:22:48.220
Sometimes when you add the idea of,
well I understand that's a country,

421
00:22:48.220 --> 00:22:51.110
I've seen that country
before I get the idea of it.

422
00:22:51.110 --> 00:22:53.170
Even though it can get abstract,

423
00:22:53.170 --> 00:22:57.150
it really brings it into more of
a solidified idea in our mind's eye.

424
00:22:57.150 --> 00:23:02.000
And again, going back to the idea of how
easily is this going to be consumed by me

425
00:23:02.000 --> 00:23:04.680
as an end-user to understand the data?

426
00:23:04.680 --> 00:23:09.065
This is a tremendous help for us, so
Ronnie we do definitely thank you on this

427
00:23:09.065 --> 00:23:11.615
one, for showing us how to implement this-
>> Cool.

428
00:23:11.615 --> 00:23:13.295
>> In our SQL environments.

429
00:23:13.295 --> 00:23:14.085
That being said,

430
00:23:14.085 --> 00:23:17.555
looks like we've come to the end of
all these great aggregate functions.

431
00:23:17.555 --> 00:23:18.565
I hope you guys have enjoyed it.

432
00:23:18.565 --> 00:23:20.075
We thank Ronnie for being here.

433
00:23:20.075 --> 00:23:23.165
We thank you guys for joining us as well,
but we're gonna go ahead and sign off for

434
00:23:23.165 --> 00:23:25.435
ITProTV, and I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

435
00:23:25.435 --> 00:23:26.125
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

436
00:23:26.125 --> 00:23:27.382
>> And we'll see you next time.

437
00:23:27.382 --> 00:23:34.069
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to query SQL Server 2014 using Synonyms, Intersects, and Excepts. They start by looking at the Synonyms, which are similar to Aliases, but are more permanent. Next they describe the use of the Intersect which returns distinct rows that are common between sets. Finally, they explore the Except which returns distinct rows that are in the first query but not the second.
episodes.title: Query Using Synonyms, Except and Intersect
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.962 --> 00:00:16.935
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.935 --> 00:00:20.887
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are continuing on with

4
00:00:20.887 --> 00:00:25.135
our series of querying the Microsoft SQL
Server version 2014, joining us back in

5
00:00:25.135 --> 00:00:29.147
studio again today to help us out with
that very endeavor is our good friend, Mr.

6
00:00:29.147 --> 00:00:29.870
Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:29.870 --> 00:00:31.710
Ronnie, welcome back to the show,
how's it going today?

8
00:00:31.710 --> 00:00:33.564
>> It is going great today,

9
00:00:33.564 --> 00:00:38.700
glad to be back with us as we continue
on to take a look at SQL 2014.

10
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:41.379
And we're specifically gonna
be taking a look at some of

11
00:00:41.379 --> 00:00:44.970
the newer code that we may actually end
up using to help us to write better and

12
00:00:44.970 --> 00:00:46.990
more efficient types of queries.

13
00:00:46.990 --> 00:00:48.920
Now, you'll not use this
in every situation, but

14
00:00:48.920 --> 00:00:53.170
you will see some situations in which
this will be beneficial for you.

15
00:00:53.170 --> 00:00:55.220
And so,
that's what we're gonna take a look at.

16
00:00:55.220 --> 00:00:59.620
We're specifically gonna be focusing in on
the idea of creating what we call synonyms

17
00:00:59.620 --> 00:01:03.300
to help us in our querying, as well as
we'll take a look at very specialized

18
00:01:03.300 --> 00:01:07.323
types of joins that we call EXCEPT and
INTERSECT as well.

19
00:01:07.323 --> 00:01:11.200
And so, understanding these things are
gonna help you to be able to query much

20
00:01:11.200 --> 00:01:14.490
more efficiently, be able to do
some of the things that, really,

21
00:01:14.490 --> 00:01:18.510
the typing is what normally gets in the
way, and we'll talk about the reason why.

22
00:01:18.510 --> 00:01:21.210
So, when we talk about
the idea of synonyms,

23
00:01:21.210 --> 00:01:24.670
especially in the English language,
we have plenty of them.

24
00:01:24.670 --> 00:01:27.210
The idea is fairly simple for most of us.

25
00:01:27.210 --> 00:01:30.330
We find a word and
we find another word that has almost, or

26
00:01:30.330 --> 00:01:33.300
if not exactly the same definition to it,
and

27
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:36.460
we end up using that word as
a replacement for the original.

28
00:01:36.460 --> 00:01:36.980
So, there it is.

29
00:01:36.980 --> 00:01:41.970
There's the grammar, as far as
Ronnie Wong knows, as far as synonyms go.

30
00:01:41.970 --> 00:01:44.520
That's the grammar lesson for today.

31
00:01:44.520 --> 00:01:45.640
But you might be wondering,

32
00:01:45.640 --> 00:01:49.800
what do synonyms have to do
with things like SQL Server?

33
00:01:49.800 --> 00:01:53.220
Well, remember that right now,
as far as best practice goes,

34
00:01:53.220 --> 00:01:57.710
when we start to actually do a type
of query, we normally go ahead and

35
00:01:57.710 --> 00:02:00.270
we type out that keyword select.

36
00:02:00.270 --> 00:02:03.473
And then, we're actually told that
we need to type out, of course,

37
00:02:03.473 --> 00:02:04.587
then that column name.

38
00:02:04.587 --> 00:02:08.875
And the best practice in that column name
though is, or I shouldn't say the best

39
00:02:08.875 --> 00:02:13.227
practice, the general accepted practice,
and the way that they recommend that

40
00:02:13.227 --> 00:02:16.301
you do it is by using what they
call that full schema name.

41
00:02:16.301 --> 00:02:20.865
And so, normally when you started
seeing things inside of our querying,

42
00:02:20.865 --> 00:02:25.207
if you remember in some other episodes
where we had to do something like

43
00:02:25.207 --> 00:02:29.549
person dot person, address, and
then the name or the street name, or

44
00:02:29.549 --> 00:02:31.550
employee department history.

45
00:02:31.550 --> 00:02:35.340
It was actually person dot
employee department history

46
00:02:35.340 --> 00:02:39.630
dot something else to actually be
able to do all those things, right?

47
00:02:39.630 --> 00:02:43.430
So, it almost looked like a DNS name,
and these names would get very long.

48
00:02:43.430 --> 00:02:48.290
Well, we actually used aliases in
previous episodes to shorten up

49
00:02:48.290 --> 00:02:52.990
that kind of schema, that hierarchy
to just use either a single letter in

50
00:02:52.990 --> 00:02:57.550
place of the actual table name, and
then dot whatever the field name is.

51
00:02:57.550 --> 00:03:00.900
And that did shorten things
up a little bit more.

52
00:03:00.900 --> 00:03:05.171
Now, with the aliases, we can actually
use those for several different things.

53
00:03:05.171 --> 00:03:09.826
But synonyms give us a little bit more
flexibility, because what synonyms allow

54
00:03:09.826 --> 00:03:14.483
us to do, is to essentially take that
entire name, regardless of how long it is,

55
00:03:14.483 --> 00:03:18.660
and condense it up and do what we want
it to do, okay, by actually calling

56
00:03:18.660 --> 00:03:23.599
on a fairly short name, depending on
what you wanna make it, to help you out.

57
00:03:24.600 --> 00:03:28.610
So, when we start actually using synonyms,
the hard thing to remember, especially

58
00:03:28.610 --> 00:03:32.389
those of us that have actually been using
databases for a long time, is that we're

59
00:03:32.389 --> 00:03:35.980
gonna create them and it's gonna create
an object inside of our database.

60
00:03:35.980 --> 00:03:40.080
But that object is not gonna
hold any real data at all.

61
00:03:40.080 --> 00:03:43.460
It is really just a name that's
essentially gonna be linked

62
00:03:43.460 --> 00:03:47.000
to the actual object that's
in our database instead.

63
00:03:47.000 --> 00:03:50.520
We're used to, at some point,
maybe creating what we call views, or

64
00:03:50.520 --> 00:03:53.530
other tables, or
anything else that we might have, but

65
00:03:53.530 --> 00:03:56.540
synonyms will instead
actually just be a name.

66
00:03:56.540 --> 00:04:01.300
Now, the neat thing is, we can actually
create synonyms for tables like we said,

67
00:04:01.300 --> 00:04:06.330
views, stored procedures,
functions that we actually come up with,

68
00:04:06.330 --> 00:04:07.860
as well as aggregation.

69
00:04:07.860 --> 00:04:09.820
So, we actually do have a lot of these.

70
00:04:09.820 --> 00:04:14.000
You might actually come up and say,
the average of all my sales, quantities,

71
00:04:14.000 --> 00:04:17.750
or the average of all my yearly sales,
whatever it might be, and

72
00:04:17.750 --> 00:04:22.150
create that as being a synonym, and
go ahead and run that entire series there

73
00:04:22.150 --> 00:04:25.340
of all the select statements and
everything else as a view, store.

74
00:04:25.340 --> 00:04:28.190
And then, actually create a shorter
name for it, if you wanted to, and

75
00:04:28.190 --> 00:04:31.640
have that stored, so it can be used very
quickly instead of having to type out

76
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:34.760
a very long type of query or
the way that you have the store view.

77
00:04:34.760 --> 00:04:38.370
>> Ronnie, it sounds a lot like when
you're describing a variable, right?

78
00:04:38.370 --> 00:04:40.970
You're saying I'm giving it a name and

79
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:43.360
now I'm inserting the value
coming from somewhere else.

80
00:04:43.360 --> 00:04:44.750
>> Right, yeah, it really is.

81
00:04:44.750 --> 00:04:47.430
It's fairly similar to that concept and
idea.

82
00:04:47.430 --> 00:04:51.314
The hard thing is to remember is that
we're not gonna create synonyms for

83
00:04:51.314 --> 00:04:55.190
something that we've created as far

are really designed to help you out

And you do wanna actually do an EXCEPT or

544

remember the idea here are synonyms.

Synonyms are very useful and can actually

You never know when you might need

00:30:40.801 --> 00:30:43.496

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at the different Data Access technologies. They start by explaining what Data Access technologies are and how they're used. This includes DA's like SQL Server Native Client(SNAC), ADO.NET, JDBC drivers, and Microsoft drivers for PHP.
episodes.title: Understand Data Access Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to work with conditional statements and NULL values. They begin by explaining the CASE function to perform decisions based on matching conditions. They then turn to the IS NULL function to test for NULL values. Finally, they explain how to use the COALESCE function to replace a NULL value with another value.
episodes.title: Work with Conditions and Nulls

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to work with table constraints. They start by using the INSERT INTO function to select data from one table and insert it into an existing table. Then they use INSERT to create a new table. Finally, they show you how to use the VALUES function.
episodes.title: Work with Table Constraints

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate how to query and manage XML data in a SQL 2014 database. They start by explaining the when and why you would be working with XML and then show you how to create XML data from relational data.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their look at querying and managing XML data in SQL 2014. Here they introduce you to the practice of "shredding" XML into tables. Finally, they explain the process of XML indexing; creating and using both primary and secondary indexes.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain using Stored Procedures in SQL 2014. They begin by introducing you to stored procedures; what they are and why they are used. Then they show you how to create a simple stored procedure utilizing both input and output parameters. Finally they go over Branching Logic controls used as conditional elements.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Stored Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore using the INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statements in SQL Server 2014. Here they look at INSERT to insert one or more rows into a target table. They show how this can be done with single values as well as multiple values. They also demonstrate using the INSERT SELECT and EXEC statements.
episodes.title: INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their discussion of INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statements in SQL Server 2014. They pick back up with the SELECT INTO statement and then jump into the UPDATE statement, explaining both ideas of deterministic and nondeterministic. Finally, they demonstrate deleting data using the DELETE statement.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate how to combine datasets. They go over the difference between UNION and UNION ALL and the rules that govern their use. They also look at modifying data with MERGE statements.
episodes.title: Combine Datasets

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to create and work with functions. They explain what functions in SQL are and look at the two types of User Defined Functions(UDFs), Scalar and Table-Valued, giving examples of each.
episodes.title: Work with Functions

WEBVTT

1

>> It's going great,
as we continue on to take a look at more

SQL Server 201S

a look at working with functions today,

Now, don't get me wrong, we can actually

And if you put in average and

42

So that is what is called

43

is that you'll normally get

44

And so average is a good one there.

45

The other one has

And a lot of these may actually

So for example, if you were to run

Well, that actually depends on the system

And it didn't matter if you actually

That's actually looking for

So just kind of realize that there

they normally do group functions into

Now the two that I actually

These are things that will exist and

So normally when you start talking

Now, when it comes down to creating UDS,

Well, there's really two types of those,

So just like we said there's actually

Most of the time, as far as I know, and

And so then once we do that we can

And we've already done some of this

Now here I have sales.

Well remember I said a scalar function

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring query optimization. They look into the Execution Plans (Actual and Estimated) and the 3 ways in which they are presented (Textual, Graphical, and XML). Also discussed are Plan Guides.

00:26:49.580 --> 00:26:51.940
We have the ability to change
essentially the T SQL,

475
00:26:51.940 --> 00:26:54.210
in other words the way
we write our statements.

476
00:26:54.210 --> 00:26:58.640
And optimize our statements at that point
or we can actually even come over here to

477
00:26:58.640 --> 00:27:02.055
the optimization and
say I want to do the optimization.

478
00:27:02.055 --> 00:27:04.680
SQL optimizer, you take a break,

479
00:27:04.680 --> 00:27:07.580
I'm gonna override the way that you
would actually tend to do that instead.

480
00:27:09.310 --> 00:27:13.000
Once I do that, let me go ahead and
turn that off completely.

481
00:27:13.000 --> 00:27:15.060
I don't need it running in the background,
so I'm gonna go ahead and

482
00:27:15.060 --> 00:27:16.330
close that one out.

483
00:27:16.330 --> 00:27:19.280
But that's just an example of some
of the things that you can do.

484
00:27:19.280 --> 00:27:22.348
Now if you are saying well where
did that command come from?

485
00:27:22.348 --> 00:27:26.128
Well that's when you actually have more
experience and you understand the options

486
00:27:26.128 --> 00:27:30.190
that you add in that will help to change
the way that the optimization takes place.

487
00:27:30.190 --> 00:27:32.480
But that comes from more
experience again and

488
00:27:32.480 --> 00:27:38.060
more of taking a look at the series as
we actually go on in SQL server 2014.

489
00:27:38.060 --> 00:27:40.220
So just kind of realize that
we're just showing you,

490
00:27:40.220 --> 00:27:42.633
just kind of the very basics and
the meat and potatoes of it.

491
00:27:42.633 --> 00:27:46.960
But overall though, using these
planning guides can be effective, okay?

492
00:27:46.960 --> 00:27:50.130
But remember it's not that
the optimizer does it badly.

493
00:27:50.130 --> 00:27:54.130
The optimizer has done a great job so
don't discount it.

494
00:27:54.130 --> 00:27:57.490
But at the same time, if you need it to
run in the way that you need it to because

495
00:27:57.490 --> 00:27:59.800
you're programming something
in the way that you want it.

496
00:27:59.800 --> 00:28:03.409
Or you're a developer and you go, this is
the way I need it to run, you have that

497
00:28:03.409 --> 00:28:06.395
chance to do that to optimize it
the way that you need it instead.

498
00:28:06.395 --> 00:28:10.677
>> Yeah, I guess as the person running
the thing, and you know you have

499
00:28:10.677 --> 00:28:14.762
that perception and conception
of what you need toward the end.

500
00:28:14.762 --> 00:28:17.870
The computer doesn't know that,
it just knows what you tell it, so

501
00:28:17.870 --> 00:28:22.040
it can't perceive a more optimized outcome
cuz it doesn't know that's the outcome

502
00:28:22.040 --> 00:28:22.950
you're looking for.

503
00:28:22.950 --> 00:28:26.100
All it can do is what you feed into, but
Ronnie, you've done a great job of showing

504
00:28:26.100 --> 00:28:28.460
us how we can help the computer-
>> [LAUGH]

505
00:28:28.460 --> 00:28:29.740
>> Understand that hey,

506
00:28:29.740 --> 00:28:33.700
I know you've got a great way doing it
there but let me show you a trick or two.

507
00:28:33.700 --> 00:28:36.500
Very very cool stuff
with using optimization.

508
00:28:36.500 --> 00:28:40.520
But again, we have yet so
plumb the depths of optimization.

509
00:28:40.520 --> 00:28:44.050
We do have a little bit more to go,
looks like a part three is on the horizon.

510
00:28:44.050 --> 00:28:45.850
That being said, I look forward
to seeing you there, Ronnie.

511
00:28:45.850 --> 00:28:47.380
We look forward to seeing
you there as well.

512
00:28:47.380 --> 00:28:49.180
We're going to go ahead and
sign off for IT ProTV.

513
00:28:49.180 --> 00:28:51.120
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

514
00:28:51.120 --> 00:28:51.994
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

515
00:28:51.994 --> 00:28:53.855
>> And we'll see you next time.

516
00:28:53.855 --> 00:28:55.520
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish exploring query optimization by looking at Dynamic Management Views and the 3 Hint types (JOIN, QUERY, and Table). Also covered are JOIN types and Nested Loops.
episodes.title: Optimize Queries Part 3

WEBVTT

And these don't take a lot of time, but

One of course, I know it's a strange

We're also gonna of course talk

Joins, I keep saying hints, but we'll

And then, of course,

Well remember that there's

Sometimes you might also hear about

But overall though, you might hear

I was trying to say office, but

So essentially, objects is the overall

Now the key behind this view is that it

Let me show you what I'm talking about,

So when we actually go ahead and take

And inside of

00:05:06.955 --> 00:05:10.790

Now when we start taking a look at this,

They added in a ton of these, so

These are all of the dynamic management

Not even close.

But just kinda realize that

Because they're actually treated as views,

Now, if we want to see it, but

Now they've added in a few more, okay.

So those views are actually there for

Now remember that what I've told you

Some of the most important ones of course

But the key here is to, well the key

Notice that as complex as that select

It's just a regular select statement.

We're saying hey look,

Well again, this is where it goes

00:08:14.080 --> 00:08:17.982
these are things that you can find out but

00:08:17.982 --> 00:08:21.090
notice, I'm not having to

00:08:21.090 --> 00:08:22.170
I'm just pulling up, what?

00:08:22.170 --> 00:08:28.260
The DMV, the Dynamic Management View,

150
00:08:29.310 --> 00:08:31.630
And when I select that,

00:08:31.630 --> 00:08:38.170
Now, if I scroll out just a little bit,

00:08:38.170 --> 00:08:41.810
It tells me my logical_cpu_count,

00:08:41.810 --> 00:08:46.900
I have 1 logical_cpu, 1 physical

00:08:46.900 --> 00:08:52.560
the time that I first started up

155
00:08:52.560 --> 00:08:57.440
So you can get information like that

156
00:08:57.440 --> 00:09:01.160
actually dig through, and go where in

00:09:01.160 --> 00:09:03.990
It could come from anywhere but

158
00:09:03.990 --> 00:09:07.900
You can actually find information like
that out very quickly and easily.

159
00:09:07.900 --> 00:09:11.240
So not only do you have stuff like
that for the operating system,

160
00:09:11.240 --> 00:09:15.350
and that is why it's different from just

161
00:09:15.350 --> 00:09:19.240
And at that point, you might also then
of course then pull up things about

00:09:23.180 --> 00:09:26.240
And this one's a little bit

00:09:26.240 --> 00:09:31.240
it doesn't inner\g join
between two views here, so

00:09:31.240 --> 00:09:36.950
notice i'm doing the interjoin between one
of the operating system types of views.

166
00:09:36.950 --> 00:09:41.080
The management views, and
one of the execution views as well.

167
00:09:43.430 --> 00:09:45.200
So, if I can actually run that.

168
00:09:45.200 --> 00:09:47.330
Let's see if that actually

00:09:47.330 --> 00:09:50.240
There we go, that actually does

00:09:50.240 --> 00:09:53.540
Well, now I can actually
see other information and

And it can actually tell

174
00:10:05.070 --> 00:10:08.160
There's actually a lot of information
that's actually available for

175
00:10:08.160 --> 00:10:09.450
us right there.

176
00:10:09.450 --> 00:10:13.370
And then lastly, we have one

00:10:13.370 --> 00:10:16.910
missing as well as other ones and so
these are actually very important,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss how SQL Server 2014 manages Transactions to ensure the database integrity. They explain how SQL 2014 uses Commits and Rollbacks to this end as well as the difference between Implicit and Explicit transactions. Also covered are the isolation levels.

00:13:13.580 --> 00:13:18.790
Every transaction that we have that

00:13:24.250 --> 00:13:26.400

So there's a couple of
ways it can be done.

466
00:25:53.830 --> 00:25:57.070
Usually it's at the power outage,
when everything's in that transaction log

467
00:25:57.070 --> 00:26:00.160
there, that all of a sudden when it
actually looks and says this is partial,

468
00:26:00.160 --> 00:26:01.972
I'm going to roll this thing back anyways.

469
00:26:01.972 --> 00:26:05.669
So it just kind of erases it out of that
transaction log, we don't actually have it

470
00:26:05.669 --> 00:26:08.580
in there anymore,
we just start all over from that point.

471
00:26:08.580 --> 00:26:12.720
So that's kind of a key here in
understanding the control and

472
00:26:12.720 --> 00:26:14.900
the message of that as well, okay?

473
00:26:16.090 --> 00:26:20.650
All right, so
there's a lot of just little bits and

474
00:26:20.650 --> 00:26:24.140
pieces of information that we just have
to know about the difference between

475
00:26:24.140 --> 00:26:27.000
the implicit and the explicit here.

476
00:26:27.000 --> 00:26:31.930
Remember that it's really those key words
here, begin tran or begin transaction.

477
00:26:31.930 --> 00:26:33.220
If you see those in there,

478
00:26:33.220 --> 00:26:36.780
that means it's gonna mark the beginning
of an explicit one, you don't see that and

479
00:26:36.780 --> 00:26:41.720
you only see the commit tran, then
that's gonna be an implicit one instead.

480
00:26:41.720 --> 00:26:46.530
And that's actually part of the idea that
we have to be able to understand and

481
00:26:46.530 --> 00:26:48.200
do, okay?

482
00:26:48.200 --> 00:26:51.870
Now there's only a couple of other
things that we need to point out so

483
00:26:51.870 --> 00:26:54.090
far as well, okay?

484
00:26:54.090 --> 00:26:59.170
And that is that because every
single transaction is isolated,

485
00:26:59.170 --> 00:27:01.770
in other words,
it's not gonna affect anybody else.

486
00:27:01.770 --> 00:27:04.920
You need to know the default
isolation levels

487
00:27:04.920 --> 00:27:09.780
in a standard SQL server residing
inside of your network, okay.

488
00:27:09.780 --> 00:27:14.460
The actual standard isolation level
is what they call read committed.

489
00:27:14.460 --> 00:27:15.340
Now what the heck does that mean?

490
00:27:15.340 --> 00:27:17.890
That means when you run
some type of query,

491
00:27:17.890 --> 00:27:22.440
you're actually getting data that's only
committed in the database itself, okay?

492
00:27:23.440 --> 00:27:30.210
But the funny thing is if you're actually
using the newer Azure SQL database itself.

493
00:27:30.210 --> 00:27:34.880
The default one is called, and
I have to make sure I say this right.

494
00:27:34.880 --> 00:27:39.290
Read committed snapshot is what
this one actually is called here,

495
00:27:39.290 --> 00:27:41.150
read committed snapshot.

496
00:27:41.150 --> 00:27:42.730
It not only gives you that ability,
of course,

497
00:27:42.730 --> 00:27:46.300
to only read the data that's in there but
any snapshots that were saved of

498
00:27:46.300 --> 00:27:49.880
the database as well is
also gonna be on there too.

499
00:27:49.880 --> 00:27:52.710
There's another one that you can also have
which is called read uncommitted that

500
00:27:52.710 --> 00:27:56.960
gives you the ability not only to get
results from the actual committed

501
00:27:56.960 --> 00:28:01.100
databases in there but
even uncommitted data that was changed and

502
00:28:01.100 --> 00:28:04.070
then rolled back a little
bit later on as well.

503
00:28:04.070 --> 00:28:07.390
So there's a couple of different
isolation levels that is in there but

504
00:28:07.390 --> 00:28:08.500
remember those defaults.

505
00:28:08.500 --> 00:28:11.480
Most of the time read committed is
probably the one that we'll deal with.

506
00:28:11.480 --> 00:28:16.034
If you're an Azure, read committed
snapshots instead those are the ones that

507
00:28:16.034 --> 00:28:18.650
won't end up seen as well, okay?

508
00:28:18.650 --> 00:28:21.900
So we should the difference now
between commit and roll back,

509
00:28:21.900 --> 00:28:26.910
we should understand that we have implicit
and explicit in that tran count 0 or

510
00:28:26.910 --> 00:28:30.770
1, very important any time
something larger than that,

511
00:28:30.770 --> 00:28:34.300
more than likely you're actually running
some kind of nested transaction.

512
00:28:34.300 --> 00:28:36.580
Not exactly the greatest thing for
the SQL server,

513
00:28:36.580 --> 00:28:38.930
but it can actually deal with it as well.

514
00:28:38.930 --> 00:28:40.410
But those are kinda the basics.

515
00:28:40.410 --> 00:28:44.850
Now if you are going, wow Ronnie that was
insanely confusing, well that's why this

516
00:28:44.850 --> 00:28:48.770
stuff is really just an introduction
rather than what we are actually gonna see

517
00:28:48.770 --> 00:28:52.740
later on when we get into actually
breaking down these transactions in

518
00:28:52.740 --> 00:28:57.590
the rest of the MCSA series for SQL 2014
>> All right well, looks like there's

519
00:28:57.590 --> 00:29:03.450
a lot of information that we have
consumed today as the learnees.

520
00:29:03.450 --> 00:29:07.340
And the teacher here giving us all that
we need to know so we can pass that exam.

521
00:29:07.340 --> 00:29:11.350
And letting us know that SQL
has some nice safety nets

522
00:29:11.350 --> 00:29:15.630
involved in case things do kind
of go south and that's good for

523
00:29:15.630 --> 00:29:20.440
us cuz the last thing we want is corrupted
databases, incomplete transactions,

524
00:29:20.440 --> 00:29:26.080
all that business can just lead to a mess
especially if you have a large database.

525
00:29:26.080 --> 00:29:27.480
Now you're in the nightmare scenario,

526
00:29:27.480 --> 00:29:29.160
and then we keep us out
of the weeds with that.

527
00:29:29.160 --> 00:29:33.360
So we thank you Ronnie for that,
we It looks like time has expired.

528
00:29:33.360 --> 00:29:35.330
We do thank you guys for joining us today.

00:29:35.330 --> 00:29:38.450
Hopefully, you enjoyed this episode and
learned something.

530

We're gonna go ahead and

00:29:40.250 --> 00:29:41.720

>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.
