episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie evaluate the use of row-based operations vs. the set-based operations. They explain when to use Cursors as well as the impact of Scalar User Defined Functions(UDFs). Also, they demonstrate combining multiple DML operations and using set-based logic rather than row-based logic.
episodes.title: Evaluate Different Operations
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.169 --> 00:00:16.618
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.618 --> 00:00:19.320
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we're continuing on our

4
00:00:19.320 --> 00:00:23.010
series of querying
the Microsoft SQL server 2014.

5
00:00:23.010 --> 00:00:26.200
Joining me back in the studio again today
to help us out with that very endeavor is

6
00:00:26.200 --> 00:00:28.280
our good friend and
mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:28.280 --> 00:00:29.460
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:29.460 --> 00:00:30.260
How's it going today?

9
00:00:30.260 --> 00:00:35.810
>> It's going great as we continue to
take a look of more of SQL server 2014.

10
00:00:35.810 --> 00:00:39.970
Today we're talking about different types
of operations that can be done inside of

11
00:00:39.970 --> 00:00:41.350
our SQL server.

12
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:44.650
Now the majority of our show centers
around what we call, of course,

13
00:00:44.650 --> 00:00:48.950
set based operations, but there are a few
things that we have done throughout this

14
00:00:48.950 --> 00:00:54.760
entire series which actually call for what
we call role based operations instead.

15
00:00:54.760 --> 00:00:58.850
And when we start to take a look
at the idea of both of them, it's

16
00:00:58.850 --> 00:01:03.130
both of them that give us the combination
of what we might actually really need,

17
00:01:03.130 --> 00:01:06.150
of course, in a very real world situation.

18
00:01:06.150 --> 00:01:08.000
Now, when we start talking about that,

19
00:01:08.000 --> 00:01:10.890
you have to understand something
about the SQL server itself.

20
00:01:10.890 --> 00:01:12.677
The SQL server, remember,

21
00:01:12.677 --> 00:01:17.667
is actually based around relational
database design itself and actually in its

22
00:01:17.667 --> 00:01:22.810
basis is the mathematical concept of set
theory right, when we start doing this.

23
00:01:22.810 --> 00:01:28.407
And so when they actually want to
retrieve records out of a SQL database,

24
00:01:28.407 --> 00:01:33.546
the whole goal and nature is to
retrieve that set of information and

25
00:01:33.546 --> 00:01:39.787
then to essentially use filters to display
to you the information that you need,

26
00:01:39.787 --> 00:01:45.516
but its native goal and its native
design is what is based on sets, right?

27
00:01:45.516 --> 00:01:50.367
So its best and most efficient use in
operation is when we do end up actually

28
00:01:50.367 --> 00:01:52.481
getting sets of information and

29
00:01:52.481 --> 00:01:57.690
then we use little things to help us
to be able to tweak what we want.

30
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:01.901
The other way of course to do
this instead is to actually do

31
00:02:01.901 --> 00:02:04.575
what we call row based operations.

32
00:02:04.575 --> 00:02:09.030
Row based operations, let's take for
example of a table, and

33
00:02:09.030 --> 00:02:14.300
what I want to do is I want to run through
that table and then individually row

34
00:02:14.300 --> 00:02:19.840
by row put some operation on
every single row in doing that.

35
00:02:19.840 --> 00:02:24.180
Now compared to the set based operation,
when I say I'm using a filter or I'm doing

36
00:02:24.180 --> 00:02:28.470
something to define that, right, it
doesn't have to go row by row to do that.

37
00:02:28.470 --> 00:02:30.970
It takes a look at the whole set here and
says, hey,

38
00:02:30.970 --> 00:02:34.550
in this column if it matches this,
just show me that, right?

39
00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:38.210
But the entire set of data's
actually way back there in the back.

40
00:02:38.210 --> 00:02:41.870
But when we talk about the idea of
here doing row based operations,

41
00:02:41.870 --> 00:02:45.830
it is taking a look at every single
row that you pull up here and saying,

42
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:49.990
I want to run this, or
I want to do this on every single row.

43
00:02:49.990 --> 00:02:51.430
Now what is that a difference of?

44
00:02:51.430 --> 00:02:54.218
Well, if you think about it,
if we just pull up a table, well,

45
00:02:54.218 --> 00:02:56.231
let's just say that that's one procedure.

46
00:02:56.231 --> 00:03:01.177
And then if I pull up a filter,
let's just say that that's two procedures,

47
00:03:01.177 --> 00:03:03.900
on however many rows that we have, okay?

48
00:03:03.900 --> 00:03:05.153
So, when we do that, right,

49
00:03:05.153 --> 00:03:08.269
that's really about two procedures
when it goes down through there, and

50
00:03:08.269 --> 00:03:12.160
if there's 10,000 rows, it really is
two procedures on 10,000 rows of data.

51
00:03:13.240 --> 00:03:18.080
But if you do a row based operation,
well beginning at row one,

52
00:03:18.080 --> 00:03:20.980
you're actually running that
procedure to pull it up.

53
00:03:20.980 --> 00:03:24.420
You're then running that, whatever
operation you're saying on that one row,

54
00:03:24.420 --> 00:03:28.450
and then proceeding on number two,
and then running that again, and

55
00:03:28.450 --> 00:03:31.280
then running it again and running
it again, as it goes on through and

56
00:03:31.280 --> 00:03:32.795
iterating through the entire thing.

57
00:03:32.795 --> 00:03:37.490
And so you might actually be running,
let's say, 10,001 procedures on

58
00:03:37.490 --> 00:03:42.230
that same one, and the weird thing is, it
can return to you the exact same result.

59
00:03:42.230 --> 00:03:47.090
Or it can return to you different results
and that's where the key comes in.

60
00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:50.450
So that's when we start talking
about which ones we should use and

61
00:03:50.450 --> 00:03:52.290
which ones we shouldn't.

62
00:03:52.290 --> 00:03:53.980
So, in everything that we do,

63
00:03:53.980 --> 00:03:56.780

64

One, not only that, cuz that's actually
what we call a costly type of procedure,

65
00:04:00.880 --> 00:04:04.190
but two, is it actually right for
what we need it to do, okay?

66
00:04:04.190 --> 00:04:06.610
So that's really where it comes down to.

67
00:04:06.610 --> 00:04:08.370
So, we've already focused in,

68
00:04:08.370 --> 00:04:12.510
like we said the entire series pretty
much on set based types of features.

69
00:04:12.510 --> 00:04:16.720
Today, we're just gonna talk
briefly about, really about two

70
00:04:16.720 --> 00:04:20.890
different ways that we can actually
encounter row based features instead.

71
00:04:20.890 --> 00:04:24.770
And of course, when we start talking
about it, best practice is this.

72
00:04:24.770 --> 00:04:28.610
Is to actually use only
row based features.

73
00:04:28.610 --> 00:04:32.150
I kept saying I'm not
gonna be able to say that.

74
00:04:32.150 --> 00:04:35.370
On what we call,
why can't I remember the term here.

75
00:04:35.370 --> 00:04:36.740
On exceptions, right?

76
00:04:36.740 --> 00:04:40.570
So it's not the norm that we
would actually run these on, but

77
00:04:40.570 --> 00:04:41.350
it's the exception.

00:04:41.350 --> 00:04:46.250
So when you can't actually get it to
determine any other way, then, yes,

79
00:04:46.250 --> 00:04:48.490
try the row based way to go.

80
00:04:48.490 --> 00:04:52.410
So I wanna show you an example of what
we're talking about here in just a moment.

81
00:04:52.410 --> 00:04:56.180
So the first one here, right, when we
start seeing it, is we're gonna actually

So here on my screen,

I'm gonna be connected to

And the first one I'm gonna do

So, if I have this object I've created I'm

Now, notice the stored procedure

Now, what does that mean?

That means on every single row,
I want it to run through this and

99

make sure that when it prints out, it

00:06:04.810 --> 00:06:07.500
then the customer ID number, okay?

So that means every single row inside of
that customer's table, customer table,

excuse me, that's what I needed to do.

So that's the process I want to
actually use in the idea here of

104
00:06:18.360 --> 00:06:21.700
showing you a row based type of action.

Now once I have that

I'm going to create something that

Now when we talk about the idea of a

A cursor is exactly what it sounds like.

It is actually gonna point row by row here

Yes, you need to go and look up this row.

So here we've started off by saying,

We're gonna declare two variables here,

called the cursor customer ID,

And then of course, there's another

Now once we do that, it's gonna open up

Fetch the next one from the same idea,

So every time it runs through and it runs,

all right start all over from zero,

Then we're gonna close out of that

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss implementing errors and error handling in SQL Server 2014. They define and discuss the types of locks and their scope of use. They also look at implementing the TRY/CATCH/THROW functions and custom error reporting.
